headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, it is more tied to a mix, and I'll turn it over to Steve for sort of a more granular explanation.
componenttext: Well, it is more tied to a mix, and I'll turn it over to Steve for sort of a more granular explanation.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: John, most of that business is the former Fort Dodge business that Pfizer picked up with the Wyeth acquisition. So you had a number of products in there, some of the ones that you may have heard would be ProMeris and LymeVax would be another one.
componenttext: John, most of that business is the former Fort Dodge business that Pfizer picked up with the Wyeth acquisition. So you had a number of products in there, some of the ones that you may have heard would be ProMeris and LymeVax would be another one.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And then finally, you mentioned that the DCC acquisition was pretty strategic for you. What are your current thoughts about expanding any or all of your segments into Europe at this point? Should we view this as a first in a series of moves to get bigger
componenttext: And then finally, you mentioned that the DCC acquisition was pretty strategic for you. What are your current thoughts about expanding any or all of your segments into Europe at this point? Should we view this as a first in a series of moves to get bigger in Europe or more of a one-off?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I would say, John, our focus is really on our Medical business at this time. We will always evaluate opportunities within all three segments across the world. But our focus, we think, we've got a great International business and also great international m
componenttext: I would say, John, our focus is really on our Medical business at this time. We will always evaluate opportunities within all three segments across the world. But our focus, we think, we've got a great International business and also great international management team, that we feel we strengthened with the DCC acquisition. So that will be our short-term focus, and we think we've got a great addition in DCC.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And our next question does come from the line of Lisa Gill with JPMorgan.
componenttext: And our next question does come from the line of Lisa Gill with JPMorgan.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I just had a couple of quick follow-on questions. First, Steve, can you just talk about agency sales? If I remember correctly, they're less on the revenue side but the gross profit dollars are generally equal. Is that correct? Is that how we should be thi
componenttext: I just had a couple of quick follow-on questions. First, Steve, can you just talk about agency sales? If I remember correctly, they're less on the revenue side but the gross profit dollars are generally equal. Is that correct? Is that how we should be thinking about as they move from being direct to agency?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: No, I wouldn't characterize it quite that way. Usually, the operating contribution is about equivalent, Lisa. At the product level, you'd obviously have a little bit of better margin than you would from an agency perspective. But the switch in the quarter
componenttext: No, I wouldn't characterize it quite that way. Usually, the operating contribution is about equivalent, Lisa. At the product level, you'd obviously have a little bit of better margin than you would from an agency perspective. But the switch in the quarter was really -- you had a combination of Merial coming back into the system. And Bayer, obviously, was coming out of the system, but the net result was quite positive for us for the quarter. I think you're seeing some of that reflected in the operating margin impact for the Vet business as well.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And then you talked about increasing the CEREC sales and doing whatever it takes, and probably adding incremental costs on the sales side. Is that in your current guidance to increase your sales that the incremental cost?
componenttext: And then you talked about increasing the CEREC sales and doing whatever it takes, and probably adding incremental costs on the sales side. Is that in your current guidance to increase your sales that the incremental cost?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, it is, Lisa. That was part of our budgeting process with our demographics. We're expanding the CEREC sales force, and then we have, I think, a very strategic and robust marketing budget for CEREC this year to drive that important product.
componenttext: Yes, it is, Lisa. That was part of our budgeting process with our demographics. We're expanding the CEREC sales force, and then we have, I think, a very strategic and robust marketing budget for CEREC this year to drive that important product.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And then just -- my last question is just around acquisitions, so your comments around medical moving into the European market. But what about other areas in the U.S. market just given that the economy has been difficult, and I'm sure a lot of the smaller
componenttext: And then just -- my last question is just around acquisitions, so your comments around medical moving into the European market. But what about other areas in the U.S. market just given that the economy has been difficult, and I'm sure a lot of the smaller players are struggling right now. Do you see opportunities to make acquisitions in any to your business lines?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Lisa, I think we see opportunities across all three businesses, and we also think we're a very good strategic partner for potential people who are selling their business. And even though times are a little bit tougher, we also think we're willing to
componenttext: Yes, Lisa, I think we see opportunities across all three businesses, and we also think we're a very good strategic partner for potential people who are selling their business. And even though times are a little bit tougher, we also think we're willing to pay very fair value for the right properties.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And so if you had to put a timeline, I mean, I know there's not any acquisitions in your current guidance. But given the fact that you haven't made an acquisition of size more recently, do you see opportunities out there, Scott, that you say, you know wha
componenttext: And so if you had to put a timeline, I mean, I know there's not any acquisitions in your current guidance. But given the fact that you haven't made an acquisition of size more recently, do you see opportunities out there, Scott, that you say, you know what, move in the next 12 months, we think that these will move or do you think it's going to be kind of a longer-term process?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's always longer term. Most of our strategic acquisitions, particularly on the dental side, have been involved around family decisions. But our ability to move quickly is probably one of our biggest assets. So we're definitely think that acquisi
componenttext: I think it's always longer term. Most of our strategic acquisitions, particularly on the dental side, have been involved around family decisions. But our ability to move quickly is probably one of our biggest assets. So we're definitely think that acquisitions -- there's a big opportunity for acquisitions going forward over the next 24 months. And as we've stated before in our capital allocation strategy, that is our number one priority for our cash, is to find good acquisitions in the three business units we're currently in.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And our next question does come from the line of Larry Marsh with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: And our next question does come from the line of Larry Marsh with Barclays Capital.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Scott, could you drill down a little bit about the trade-up program? It's got to be disappointing. I think you and Paul were pretty adamant about hitting the target from last year. And I was kind of curious to see that you've gotten -- it's caused you to
componenttext: Scott, could you drill down a little bit about the trade-up program? It's got to be disappointing. I think you and Paul were pretty adamant about hitting the target from last year. And I was kind of curious to see that you've gotten -- it's caused you to have to pull down your expectations. What is it that's keeping? Is it just, I guess, the environment has gotten worse in your mind? And when you think about 1,600 as your target, as we think about it, are you within 10% to 15% of that or does it really depend on this week?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's going to come down to how we finish it off, Larry. I would say we're disappointed. But once again, we want to place high expectations on the business and I still think it's a very successful total trade-up program when you combine the two yea
componenttext: I think it's going to come down to how we finish it off, Larry. I would say we're disappointed. But once again, we want to place high expectations on the business and I still think it's a very successful total trade-up program when you combine the two years and speaks to how Sirona is driving innovation, and CEREC is a product that's going to continue to evolve and get better and better over time. So while we may be disappointed that we're not going to get to the 1,600, we're extremely bullish on the future of CEREC.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And then when you talk about resources to get to the up 10% number, are these resources that are above and beyond which you had targeted at the beginning of the year?
componenttext: And then when you talk about resources to get to the up 10% number, are these resources that are above and beyond which you had targeted at the beginning of the year?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: No. This is all things that we had planned into the year when we sit down with our partners at Sirona and plan out the year. So I will remind you, too, that the first quarter is historically the smallest revenue quarter for CEREC. And so the test for us w
componenttext: No. This is all things that we had planned into the year when we sit down with our partners at Sirona and plan out the year. So I will remind you, too, that the first quarter is historically the smallest revenue quarter for CEREC. And so the test for us will be our performance, particularly in selling new units over the next nine months.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Can you share any sort of customer feedback as to what kept actions a bit different than what you would have thought? Was it, I guess, the general range of comments around the economy and the product, or is there anything more specific you heard?
componenttext:
Can you share any sort of customer feedback as to what kept actions a bit different than what you would have thought? Was it, I guess, the general range of comments around the economy and the product, or is there anything more specific you 
heard?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, nothing more specific. We've been selling in a tough economy here for 24 months. So I would say, it's nothing that we have not seen in the last two years of operating.
componenttext: Yes, nothing more specific. We've been selling in a tough economy here for 24 months. So I would say, it's nothing that we have not seen in the last two years of operating.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Certainly then just take us on the balance sheet, Steve, you talked about inventories up partly due to DCC. I would assume that's only $7 million or $8 million of that inventory boost sequentially. I don't know if that's right. So you're saying on a fair
componenttext: Certainly then just take us on the balance sheet, Steve, you talked about inventories up partly due to DCC. I would assume that's only $7 million or $8 million of that inventory boost sequentially. I don't know if that's right. So you're saying on a fair amount of the CEREC inventory, when do we see that coming? Do you just like seeing it come down here in the next quarter, or is that going to take two more quarters? And how much reduction are you hoping to get out of inventories?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: The acquisition impact, Larry, was about double what you mentioned. And then as far as working out the CEREC inventory, that is only dependent on the capabilities of our sales force, which we have great faith in. So it will happen, we think, very quickly.
componenttext: The acquisition impact, Larry, was about double what you mentioned. And then as far as working out the CEREC inventory, that is only dependent on the capabilities of our sales force, which we have great faith in. So it will happen, we think, very quickly.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And then just, Steve, I know last quarter, you talked about, I think, you alluded to $62 million of customer finance. The business that was in a roll off this quarter, that would've been a positive to cash flow. Obviously, that was somewhat offset by the
componenttext: And then just, Steve, I know last quarter, you talked about, I think, you alluded to $62 million of customer finance. The business that was in a roll off this quarter, that would've been a positive to cash flow. Obviously, that was somewhat offset by the boost in the inventory. But what else was in there that would have caused a negative year-over-year comp like in light of what I thought was going to be a good cash flow quarter?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Most of that, Larry, has to do with the liability side of our balance sheet. If you look at down the current liability section, you'll see that both payables and our accruals are down. And that's due to really the activity between the two years. So you've
componenttext: Most of that, Larry, has to do with the liability side of our balance sheet. If you look at down the current liability section, you'll see that both payables and our accruals are down. And that's due to really the activity between the two years. So you've got, last year, we were actually building in those two categories in the first quarter because of some timing and some activity. This year, we actually paid them down, so you kind of have sort of a double whammy. Most of it is in the payable side and accrual side. We had bonuses we paid off this year. We had, under the new commissioned program, we had commissioned holdback that was paid off. And then just due to the timing of the payables and the way all the weeks fell, your trade payables came down.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Two other quick things. Just to get you to really reflect again, Scott, on the consumables market environment, would you define the market to be currently flat, so you're basically growing at market? Is that how you're thinking of it? And isn't that a lit
componenttext: Two other quick things. Just to get you to really reflect again, Scott, on the consumables market environment, would you define the market to be currently flat, so you're basically growing at market? Is that how you're thinking of it? And isn't that a little bit worse than what you have thought three months ago?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I think we're going at or slightly above market when we look at all the data points between our manufacturer, partners and industry reports. And so our hope is that we were going to see some lift per consumer demand, but it was a fairly quiet sum
componenttext: Yes, and I think we're going at or slightly above market when we look at all the data points between our manufacturer, partners and industry reports. And so our hope is that we were going to see some lift per consumer demand, but it was a fairly quiet summer. And our hope that the second half of the year, we're going to see some lift. I would say, Larry, both from internal programs and from just general demand lift.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I know, Steve, you quantified exactly the benefit with the extra week. I think last quarter, you said, it would be about $0.02 to $0.04. Do we think of it as about a $0.03 benefit in EPS, or are you able to quantify that any more specifically?
componenttext: I know, Steve, you quantified exactly the benefit with the extra week. I think last quarter, you said, it would be about $0.02 to $0.04. Do we think of it as about a $0.03 benefit in EPS, or are you able to quantify that any more specifically?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: We've never really brought that down, Larry. I think we've talked about a $0.02 to $0.04 range and it's somewhere in that range. It's no more than $0.04 and probably no less than $0.02.
componenttext: We've never really brought that down, Larry. I think we've talked about a $0.02 to $0.04 range and it's somewhere in that range. It's no more than $0.04 and probably no less than $0.02.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And then just sort of sequentially, normal, your second quarter is a little bit higher than first. And I know you don't guide the quarters, but if you sort of back out let's just say the midpoint of that $0.03, is there any reason to think that the second
componenttext: And then just sort of sequentially, normal, your second quarter is a little bit higher than first. And I know you don't guide the quarters, but if you sort of back out let's just say the midpoint of that $0.03, is there any reason to think that the second quarter would actually be up or flat sequentially given you got the boost in the first quarter or is it too early to tell?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: As you had said, we don't give quarterly guidance anymore, but I think you're moving around the data point.
componenttext: As you had said, we don't give quarterly guidance anymore, but I think you're moving around the data point.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our next question does come from the line of Steven Valiquette with UBS.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our next question does come from the line of Steven Valiquette with UBS.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Say on the DCC acquisition, it seems like even with the integration cost that you mentioned, seems like it's still -- I'm having a hard time making that deal only be neutral to earnings for this year. So I'm wondering if either of the margin profile are a
componenttext: Say on the DCC acquisition, it seems like even with the integration cost that you mentioned, seems like it's still -- I'm having a hard time making that deal only be neutral to earnings for this year. So I'm wondering if either of the margin profile are a bit lower than in the overall Medical average? Or perhaps if you can just quantify what the integration costs are going to be from your point of view? I think it has to be something in the $5 million to $10 million range to have the deal only be neutral. So I just wanted to get a little more color around that?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Steve, this is Steve Armstrong. You hit on the point. It's really in the margins of the acquired business. They were quite a bit weaker than ours at the time we acquired that business. We think there's significant opportunity to improve them. We get them
componenttext: Steve, this is Steve Armstrong. You hit on the point. It's really in the margins of the acquired business. They were quite a bit weaker than ours at the time we acquired that business. We think there's significant opportunity to improve them. We get them up at least equal to our margins in our Medical business, but it's going to take some work, and part of that is the integration and the consolidation of the operation.

componenttext: And we were up 90% a year ago and we were down 20% to that in this quarter.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And our next question does come from the line of Bob Willoughby with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: And our next question does come from the line of Bob Willoughby with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

componenttext: Perfect timing, Bob. We still have the acquisition capability. The repurchase authorization, we'll continue to use it.

componenttext: No. Not at this point.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I know at one point, Steve, you talked about possibly doing something on a more automated basis. Is that a possibility that we will see something every quarter? Or is it going to be much more opportunistic?
componenttext: I know at one point, Steve, you talked about possibly doing something on a more automated basis. Is that a possibility that we will see something every quarter? Or is it going to be much more opportunistic?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I think the answer to your question Bob is, yes, you'll probably see something more active as we go forward into 2011. Again, watching the cash balance and making sure we've got enough to do what we need to do if acquisitions materialize. I think it's bee
componenttext: I think the answer to your question Bob is, yes, you'll probably see something more active as we go forward into 2011. Again, watching the cash balance and making sure we've got enough to do what we need to do if acquisitions materialize. I think it's been the priority as we get deeper into the year. I think you could see us more active in the repurchase program.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And then as far as any backlog, you did say last quarter that you had a bit of a backlog. Was this part of the backlog that was filled in the quarter? Or has the backlog continued to increase?
componenttext: And then as far as any backlog, you did say last quarter that you had a bit of a backlog. Was this part of the backlog that was filled in the quarter? Or has the backlog continued to increase?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we're seeing increased activity in backlog. We're not back to levels 2.5 years ago, but in terms of backlog and incoming orders into our top manufacturers. And anecdotally, just pure activity from our equipment sales specialist that we monit
componenttext: Well, I think we're seeing increased activity in backlog. We're not back to levels 2.5 years ago, but in terms of backlog and incoming orders into our top manufacturers. And anecdotally, just pure activity from our equipment sales specialist that we monitor. We feel comfortable that we're definitely gaining ground on prior year and look to see improved equipment sales throughout the balance of the year.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And then just on the CEREC questions, I know a lot of these was discussed earlier. But it seems to me that when you talk to Sirona, you hear about their big promotional activities planned for this weekend. They got 2,000 doctors attending the show. Do you
componenttext: And then just on the CEREC questions, I know a lot of these was discussed earlier. But it seems to me that when you talk to Sirona, you hear about their big promotional activities planned for this weekend. They got 2,000 doctors attending the show. Do you think that there's been some deferral of orders as a result of that? And do you think there's anything to read into the strong GALILEO sales to say that perhaps, that's one part of a two-part system that they're selling. Do you think there was some deferral CEREC as it relates to new users, especially around the show?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I wouldn't peg it on deferral, Derek. We're very excited about how successful the Las Vegas show is in terms of number of attendees, well over 2,000 doctors. A lot of those are current owners, which we think helps fuel GALILEO sales. But you're right
componenttext: Yes, I wouldn't peg it on deferral, Derek. We're very excited about how successful the Las Vegas show is in terms of number of attendees, well over 2,000 doctors. A lot of those are current owners, which we think helps fuel GALILEO sales. But you're right, it is a system, and that's one of the reasons why we are so committed to this long term as we think the Sirona technology and the technology of some of our other partners is really going to help change dentistry. And that's why we take a real long-term view on the CEREC product.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And is there anything signaling you in terms of your technical sales and service department , the -- you have nice increase in the total category. But I'm just wondering, are we seeing doctors kind of nurse along older chairs and units that are kind of we
componenttext: And is there anything signaling you in terms of your technical sales and service department , the -- you have nice increase in the total category. But I'm just wondering, are we seeing doctors kind of nurse along older chairs and units that are kind of wearing out? And is that why we're seeing an increase in some of those parts and labor sales?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Derek, I think that's definitely been a trend the last two years as dentist have been a little more cautious on their capital spend. And if they can fix something and particularly, the Chair business has been affected by that. And I think that's just
componenttext: Yes, Derek, I think that's definitely been a trend the last two years as dentist have been a little more cautious on their capital spend. And if they can fix something and particularly, the Chair business has been affected by that. And I think that's just, to me, strengthens the value proposition that our sales people have in terms of how important the technical services to the overall relationship. But the dentist will not defer forever. We know that they're going to have to shield some taxes and the upcoming calendar fourth quarter. And we think we've got good programs and great products with our partners to gain more than our fair share of this pent-up demand.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: The last question is on the Medical side. You're getting to a nice critical mass now on a global basis and just wondered if you've identified any additional product categories that look good for in terms of a vertical-integration opportunity?
componenttext: The last question is on the Medical side. You're getting to a nice critical mass now on a global basis and just wondered if you've identified any additional product categories that look good for in terms of a vertical-integration opportunity?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we wouldn't disclose that. I would just echo that we really feel good about our Medical business in total. I was just at their national sales meeting this week. And we've got a fantastic group of sales people and a great management team and that busi
componenttext: Yes, we wouldn't disclose that. I would just echo that we really feel good about our Medical business in total. I was just at their national sales meeting this week. And we've got a fantastic group of sales people and a great management team and that business has a lot of momentum. And really, we feel is going to be a key growth driver for Patterson Companies for years to come.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our next question does come from the line of Jeff Johnson with Robert W. Baird.

componenttext: And then a lot of focus here on why aren't the markets getting better or may be your investors are slightly disappointed markets aren't getting any better. But I think, if you step back, obviously, we've seen a lot of other areas of healthcare utilizations coming down in the calendar Q2, and a lot of questions arising around slowing utilization rate. It doesn't sound to me like you're really seeing that across any of your segments and not that flat. Nobody is going to be thrilled with flat. But at the same time, it seems to me like your remarks are a little more encouraging than what we're hearing from a lot of other healthcare companies out there that are dealing with falling utilization rate. Any comments around that?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I know, I would agree with your comments. And I think we feel like the markets have stabilized or still, we think tremendous demand just in pure demographics in all three of our business units. And you're right, it's no fun operating in a flat busine
componenttext: Yes, I know, I would agree with your comments. And I think we feel like the markets have stabilized or still, we think tremendous demand just in pure demographics in all three of our business units. And you're right, it's no fun operating in a flat business environment. But I think all three of our markets are stable and we'll look to grow them internally until we get some wind at our back.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and thank you for standing by, and welcome to the Patterson Companies First Quarter Fiscal 2011 Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Scott Anderson, President and
componenttext: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and thank you for standing by, and welcome to the Patterson Companies First Quarter Fiscal 2011 Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Scott Anderson, President and Chief Executive Officer. Please go ahead.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Craig. Good morning, and thanks for participating in our first quarter earnings conference call. Joining me today is Steve Armstrong, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. At the conclusion of our formal remarks, Steve and I
componenttext:
Thank you, Craig. Good morning, and thanks for participating in our first quarter earnings conference call. Joining me today is Steve Armstrong, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. At the conclusion of our formal remarks, Steve and I will be pleased to take your questions. Since Regulation FD prohibits us from providing investors with any earnings guidance unless we release that information simultaneously, we provided financial guidance for fiscal year 2011 in our press release earlier this morning. Our guidance is subject to a number of risks and uncertainties that could cause Patterson's actual results to vary from our forecast. These risks and uncertainties are discussed in detail in our annual report in Form 10-K and our other SEC filings, and we urge you to review this material.
As a reminder, our first quarter results included the impact of an extra 14th week, which will make fiscal 2011 a 53-week year ending on April 30, 2011.  It's difficult to quantify the exact impact of this additional week on our first quarter results, but we will provide estimates in those areas where it is possible to make reasonable approximations.
In the first quarter, consolidated sales of $850 million rose 8% from $790 million in the year-earlier period. The impact of the additional week is estimated to be approximately five percentage points. Net income of $54 million or $0.45 per diluted share rose 20% from $45 million or $0.38 per diluted share in the first quarter of fiscal 2010. We're generally pleased with Patterson's first quarter results, considering the ongoing effect of sluggish economic conditions within our served markets.
Sales of Patterson Dental Supply increased 6% to $543 million in this year's first quarter. Sales of consumable dental supplies rose 7% from last year's first quarter, and were essentially unchanged from the year-earlier period after excluding the impact of the additional week. Our Consumable business is continuing to be affected by uneven patient demand for dental services as a result of the soft economy. However, our consumable results over the past few quarters suggest that the overall dental market is stabilizing. As we predicted earlier this calendar year, consumable demand has remained soft throughout the summer, but we believe there could be modest growth during the latter half of our fiscal year. 
At the same time, we are encouraged by the strong sales growth of our non-CEREC equipment, which was up 13% in the quarter, including a 17% in basic dental equipment. The 17% increase was led by sales of cone beam and panoramic imaging system, but sales in all major categories including chairs, units, cabinetry and lighting grew in the quarter. It needs to be pointed out that it is difficult to measure the impact of an extra week on equipment sales due to such factors as the length of time from initial order installation, which can span several months between quarters. Even so, we believe that sales of basic dental equipment still would've been solidly higher on a fully comparable year-over-year basis. We believe this growth reflects our ability to capture significant share of the Equipment business that has been deferred for the past two years.
Sales of digital sensors and CEREC equipment were down in the first quarter reflecting a strong comparable sales level that each of these categories faced versus the last year's first quarter. The strength of our CEREC line in the first quarter of fiscal 2010 was generated primarily by the high level of interest in our initial trade-up program following the introduction of the CEREC AC imaging unit early in calendar 2009. A similar CEREC trade-up program has been running through this year's first quarter and will end later this month.
For the full year, we continue to believe that CEREC sales should increase by at least 10%, and we are committing substantial marketing resources to accomplish this goal. Digital sensors sales in last year first quarter were aided by a financing promotion that was not run this year.
Turning now to Webster Veterinary. Sales of our veterinary unit increased 6% in the first quarter of fiscal 2011 to $180 million. We were generally pleased with Webster's first quarter performance, including the solidly higher equipment sales reported for this period. Equipment, which constitutes a relatively small but growing portion of Webster's revenue stream, represents a key facet of Webster's drive to expand and strengthen its value-added proposition. Steve will provide greater detail in a few minutes, but we estimate that the impact of the additional week was largely offset by several factors that adversely affected the comparability of Webster's sales, including changes in the distribution arrangements for certain pharmaceuticals and the exiting of Production Animal business that was part of Columbus Serum operation prior to its acquisition. As a result, we believe Webster's reported 6% sales growth reflects the performance of its ongoing business in the first quarter. I want to add that Webster will continue to experience the impact of the sales mix shift and the absence of the Large Animal business on its sales for approximately two more quarters.
Sales of Patterson Medical, our rehabilitation supply and equipment unit, increased 17% to $127 million in this year's first quarter. Acquisitions contributed approximately 10 percentage points of Patterson Medical's first quarter sales growth, while the additional week accounted for approximately five percentage points. We believe the overall rehabilitation market continue to firm in the first quarter and that Patterson Medical continue to increase its share of the global rehabilitation market during this period. 
The acquisition that benefited Patterson Medical's first quarter performance included Empi Therapy Solutions in June 2009 and the Rehabilitation business of DCC Healthcare in June 2010. The previously reported DCC acquisition is of particular strategic importance. The acquired DCC business ranked among the leaders in their respective overseas markets, and had combined sales of approximately $70 million for their fiscal year that ended March 31, 2010. They provide assisted-living products and rehabilitation equipment and supplies to hospitals, physical and occupational therapists, long-term care facilities, dealers and consumers in the U.K. and continental Europe. 
In addition to significantly strengthening the market presence and geographic reach of our Homecraft Rolyan unit in U.K., the acquired businesses bring a stable of trusted and established brands that encompass an extensive range of products. The integration of the acquired units is proceeding on schedule and expenses related to the DCC transaction are expected to gradually moderate over the next several quarters. 
We are not anticipating any meaningful contribution to our earnings from this acquisition for the remainder of fiscal 2011 after factoring in the cost of integration and the incremental amortization of intangible assets arising from the valuation process. We believe our Rehabilitation business is positioned as a strong growth driver going forward, and we are continuing to evaluate additional acquisition opportunities for this business.
Regarding the financial outlook contained in this morning's release, our expectations for fiscal 2011 have not changed from our previously issued guidance. And we are maintaining our earnings forecast of $1.89 to $1.99 per diluted share for the full year.
Looking ahead, the health of our dental, veterinary and rehabilitation markets is gradually strengthening, and all have compelling long-term growth opportunities. Our three businesses are well positioned to capitalize on these. Moreover, we're generating substantial operating cash flows, providing us with ample resources for supporting our various growth initiatives. All in all, we are optimistic about Patterson's future. 
Thank you. Now Steve Armstrong will review some operational highlights from our first quarter performance.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Scott. Good morning, everyone. On a consolidated basis, acquisitions accounted for 1.6 percentage points of our revenue growth for the quarter, while currency exchange had a minimal impact. As Scott mentioned, within our Veterinary segment, the
componenttext:
Thank you, Scott. Good morning, everyone. On a consolidated basis, acquisitions accounted for 1.6 percentage points of our revenue growth for the quarter, while currency exchange had a minimal impact. As Scott mentioned, within our Veterinary segment, the impact of the extra selling week was offset by a number of factors that adversely affected the comparability of Webster's first quarter sales. First, Webster experienced a shift in its mix toward more agency sales in flea and tick and heartworm categories. Second, Webster's sales were negatively affected by our decision to exit the Production Animal business. It was part of the Columbus Serum operations prior to its acquisition. This occurred primarily in the third and the fourth quarters of fiscal 2010. And third, as a result of the various pharmaceutical mergers over the past few years, certain products previously sold through distribution are now being sold direct by the manufacturer. 
After taking these factors into consideration, which are expected to continue affecting Webster's sales for roughly two more quarters, we believe Webster's reported 6% sales growth reflects the performance of its ongoing business in the first quarter. As further support, we also know that our actual dosages in flea and tick and heartworm shift for the first six months of the calendar year have increased at a double-digit rate. In a market that is showing very low growth at the current time, Webster is performing very well on a comparable basis.
The Medical segment sales performance was clouded by some residual impact from the Mobilis acquisition that was completed in April 2009. As the integration of the various Mobilis entities progressed, it was necessary to step away from certain unprofitable business, and this decision affected the comparability of this quarter's sales results. When this unprofitable business is excluded from the prior year's quarter, the Medical segment would have reported solid internal growth in the mid single digits. Again, very good results in a slow market.
Moving on to our consolidated gross margin. We saw an improvement of 20 basis points from the prior year. The gross margins of the Veterinary and Medical segments both improved for the quarter as product mix and rebates favorably impacted their results. We garnered operating expense leverage in the quarter due to expense control measures we have taken over the past year in addition to the benefit of the extra week and its impact on the fixed cost.  This improvement was muted due to expenses related to the integration of the acquired DCC rehabilitation assets and the due diligence costs associated with this transaction. The due diligence and other acquisition costs included in operations for the quarter were approximately $1.5 million. By segment, our first quarter operating profits were 11.2% for Dental, 13.5% for Medical and 6% for Veterinary.
Our income tax rate reflects the benefit of the deductibility of the cash dividends paid to our employee stock ownership plan in the current period. As you will recall, we began our cash dividend program in the fourth quarter of this past fiscal year. A quick view of our balance sheet reveals that inventory levels increased by approximately $47 million at the end of this year's first quarter compared to the balance at the end of fiscal 2010.  This expansion resulted from the acquisition of the DCC assets as well as from a temporary-incremental increase in CEREC inventory, and meet anticipated sales generated by our current trade-up program and the 25th anniversary events occurring later this month.
Our DSOs stand 44 days compared to the same 44 days in the prior year, while inventory turns are 7.1 compared to 7.0 a year ago. The DSO for each period excludes the impact of finance contracts that were generated during various promotions over the past two years, through which the customer was provided payment and interest holiday periods. These contracts have been or will be sold to our regular funding sources in due course. 
We generated cash flow from operations of approximately $23 million in the first quarter compared to $47 million in the year-earlier period. In addition to the temporary inventory build noted previously, the timing of our cash disbursement cycle reduced our accounts payable balances in the first quarter of this fiscal year. We would expect both of these factors to reverse by the end of the fiscal year. 
With that, I'll turn it back to the conference operator who will poll you for your questions. Craig?

componenttext: Scott, I just want to follow up on some comments you made in your prepared remarks. You sort of suggested that you had anticipated the consumable growth rate to be relatively flat over the summer, which is what we've seen. And then, you said you kind of expect to see that consumable number growth rate accelerate in the back half. Could you maybe give us a little bit of a better sense for what might drive that accelerated growth in the back half?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, Glen. Our hope is one of two things, is that we see some improvement in consumer confidence, and we also see some deferral of dentistry. I think, when you look at the calendar fourth quarter and patients coming in, that's usually one of the biggest
componenttext: Sure, Glen. Our hope is one of two things, is that we see some improvement in consumer confidence, and we also see some deferral of dentistry. I think, when you look at the calendar fourth quarter and patients coming in, that's usually one of the biggest quarters for the dentist, patients coming back and using up insurance. Our hope is that we'll see some modest acceleration there. But still, as you know, the two key indicators really are unemployment and consumer confidence going forward. And our hope is we'll see some easing and improvement on that. We definitely feel the market has stabilized, and we see that throughout our industry context and our manufacturing partners. But our hope is the growth would be on the second half of the year.

componenttext: Yes, we don't break out specifics on that, Glen. But when we talk about basic, the cone beam and pans and chairs, units, lights are all lumped into that. But we're having very nice success, particularly with the GALILEO's line from Sirona.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And then, with respect to CEREC, the trade-up program ends later this month. Have you been relatively happy with the progress? Because going back to last quarter, you were sort of suggested you were looking for 15% growth in CEREC and now, kind of maybe l
componenttext: And then, with respect to CEREC, the trade-up program ends later this month. Have you been relatively happy with the progress? Because going back to last quarter, you were sort of suggested you were looking for 15% growth in CEREC and now, kind of maybe looks like 10%. Has anything changed or anything to read into the trade-up program or...

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: No, I think we definitely exceeded our expectations a year ago. And the trade-up program was very front-end loaded into the early part of the quarter because we have a lot of customers who had just bought the old model and then turned around and traded up
componenttext: No, I think we definitely exceeded our expectations a year ago. And the trade-up program was very front-end loaded into the early part of the quarter because we have a lot of customers who had just bought the old model and then turned around and traded up. We're still committed to double-digit growth with CEREC and are long-term believers, as you know, in the product. The key to that growth really is going to be new unit sales, and it will be the key that our year is really going to be the third and fourth quarter, which are the biggest quarters for CEREC.

componenttextpreview: It is, John. I would say our hope was that we would equal what we we're going to do last year when we sold roughly 1,600 units. We'll probably come in below that, it will still be successful. But our expectations were very high, and we'll see how we end u
componenttext: It is, John. I would say our hope was that we would equal what we we're going to do last year when we sold roughly 1,600 units. We'll probably come in below that, it will still be successful. But our expectations were very high, and we'll see how we end up the month here. And as you know, most trade-up programs or promotions, people run very hard at the end. So a lot will depend on how we finish up this week and the weekend event in Las Vegas as well.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I believe you mentioned earlier on the call some products within the Webster business that have started to go direct. Can you just elaborate on what those products are, at least, what classes that's in?
componenttext: I believe you mentioned earlier on the call some products within the Webster business that have started to go direct. Can you just elaborate on what those products are, at least, what classes that's in?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, it is more tied to a mix, and I'll turn it over to Steve for sort of a more granular explanation.
componenttext: Well, it is more tied to a mix, and I'll turn it over to Steve for sort of a more granular explanation.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: John, most of that business is the former Fort Dodge business that Pfizer picked up with the Wyeth acquisition. So you had a number of products in there, some of the ones that you may have heard would be ProMeris and LymeVax would be another one.
componenttext: John, most of that business is the former Fort Dodge business that Pfizer picked up with the Wyeth acquisition. So you had a number of products in there, some of the ones that you may have heard would be ProMeris and LymeVax would be another one.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And then finally, you mentioned that the DCC acquisition was pretty strategic for you. What are your current thoughts about expanding any or all of your segments into Europe at this point? Should we view this as the first in a series of moves to get bigge
componenttext: And then finally, you mentioned that the DCC acquisition was pretty strategic for you. What are your current thoughts about expanding any or all of your segments into Europe at this point? Should we view this as the first in a series of moves to get bigger in Europe or more of a one-off?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I would say, John, our focus is really on our Medical business at this time. We will always evaluate opportunities within all three segments across the world. But our focus, we think, we've got a great International business and also great international m
componenttext: I would say, John, our focus is really on our Medical business at this time. We will always evaluate opportunities within all three segments across the world. But our focus, we think, we've got a great International business and also great international management team, that we feel we strengthened with the DCC acquisition. So that will be our short-term focus, and we think we've got a great addition in DCC.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And our next question does come from the line of Lisa Gill with JPMorgan.
componenttext: And our next question does come from the line of Lisa Gill with JPMorgan.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I just had a couple of quick follow-on questions. First, Steve, can you just talk about agency sales? If I remember correctly, they're less on the revenue side but the gross profit dollars are generally equal. Is that correct? Is that how we should be thi
componenttext: I just had a couple of quick follow-on questions. First, Steve, can you just talk about agency sales? If I remember correctly, they're less on the revenue side but the gross profit dollars are generally equal. Is that correct? Is that how we should be thinking about as they move from being direct to agency?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: No, I wouldn't characterize it quite that way. Usually, the operating contribution is about equivalent, Lisa. At the product level, you'd obviously have a little bit of better margin than you would from an agency perspective. But the switch in the quarter
componenttext: No, I wouldn't characterize it quite that way. Usually, the operating contribution is about equivalent, Lisa. At the product level, you'd obviously have a little bit of better margin than you would from an agency perspective. But the switch in the quarter was really -- you had a combination of Merial coming back into the system. And Bayer, obviously, was coming out of the system, but the net result was quite positive for us for the quarter. I think you're seeing some of that reflected in the operating margin impact for the Vet business as well.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And then you talked about increasing the CEREC sales and doing whatever it takes, and probably adding incremental costs on the sales side. Is that in your current guidance to increase your sales that the incremental cost?
componenttext: And then you talked about increasing the CEREC sales and doing whatever it takes, and probably adding incremental costs on the sales side. Is that in your current guidance to increase your sales that the incremental cost?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, it is, Lisa. That was part of our budgeting process with our demographics. We're expanding the CEREC sales force, and then we have, I think, a very strategic and robust marketing budget for CEREC this year to drive that important product.
componenttext: Yes, it is, Lisa. That was part of our budgeting process with our demographics. We're expanding the CEREC sales force, and then we have, I think, a very strategic and robust marketing budget for CEREC this year to drive that important product.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And then just -- my last question is just around acquisitions, so your comments around medical moving into the European market. But what about other areas in the U.S. market just given that the economy has been difficult, and I'm sure a lot of the smaller
componenttext: And then just -- my last question is just around acquisitions, so your comments around medical moving into the European market. But what about other areas in the U.S. market just given that the economy has been difficult, and I'm sure a lot of the smaller players are struggling right now. Do you see opportunities to make acquisitions in any to your business lines?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Lisa, I think we see opportunities across all three businesses, and we also think we're a very good strategic partner for potential people who are selling their business. And even though times are a little bit tougher, we also think we're willing to
componenttext: Yes, Lisa, I think we see opportunities across all three businesses, and we also think we're a very good strategic partner for potential people who are selling their business. And even though times are a little bit tougher, we also think we're willing to pay very fair value for the right properties.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And so if you had to put a timeline, I mean, I know there's not any acquisitions in your current guidance. But given the fact that you haven't made an acquisition of size more recently, do you see opportunities out there, Scott, that you say, you know wha
componenttext: And so if you had to put a timeline, I mean, I know there's not any acquisitions in your current guidance. But given the fact that you haven't made an acquisition of size more recently, do you see opportunities out there, Scott, that you say, you know what, move in the next 12 months, we think that these will move or do you think it's going to be kind of a longer-term process?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's always longer term. Most of our strategic acquisitions, particularly on the dental side, have been involved around family decisions. But our ability to move quickly is probably one of our biggest assets. So we're definitely think that acquisi
componenttext: I think it's always longer term. Most of our strategic acquisitions, particularly on the dental side, have been involved around family decisions. But our ability to move quickly is probably one of our biggest assets. So we're definitely think that acquisitions -- there's a big opportunity for acquisitions going forward over the next 24 months. And as we've stated before in our capital allocation strategy, that is our number one priority for our cash, is to find good acquisitions in the three business units we're currently in.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And our next question does come from the line of Larry Marsh with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: And our next question does come from the line of Larry Marsh with Barclays Capital.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Scott, could you drill down a little bit about the trade-up program? It's got to be disappointing. I think you and Paul were pretty adamant about hitting the target from last year. And I was kind of curious to see that you've gotten -- it's caused you to
componenttext: Scott, could you drill down a little bit about the trade-up program? It's got to be disappointing. I think you and Paul were pretty adamant about hitting the target from last year. And I was kind of curious to see that you've gotten -- it's caused you to have to pull down your expectations. What is it that's keeping? Is it just, I guess, the environment has gotten worse in your mind? And when you think about 1,600 as your target, as we think about it, are you within 10% to 15% of that or does it really depend on this week?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's going to come down to how we finish it off, Larry. I would say we're disappointed. But once again, we want to place high expectations on the business and I still think it's a very successful total trade-up program when you combine the two yea
componenttext: I think it's going to come down to how we finish it off, Larry. I would say we're disappointed. But once again, we want to place high expectations on the business and I still think it's a very successful total trade-up program when you combine the two years and speaks to how Sirona is driving innovation, and CEREC is a product that's going to continue to evolve and get better and better over time. So while we may be disappointed that we're not going to get to the 1,600, we're extremely bullish on the future of CEREC.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And then when you talk about resources to get to the up 10% number, are these resources that are above and beyond which you had targeted at the beginning of the year?
componenttext: And then when you talk about resources to get to the up 10% number, are these resources that are above and beyond which you had targeted at the beginning of the year?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: No. This is all things that we had planned into the year when we sit down with our partners at Sirona and plan out the year. So I will remind you, too, that the first quarter is historically the smallest revenue quarter for CEREC. And so the test for us w
componenttext: No. This is all things that we had planned into the year when we sit down with our partners at Sirona and plan out the year. So I will remind you, too, that the first quarter is historically the smallest revenue quarter for CEREC. And so the test for us will be our performance, particularly in selling new units over the next nine months.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Can you share any sort of customer feedback as to what kept actions a bit different than what you would have thought? Was it, I guess, the general range of comments around the economy and the product, or is there anything more specific you heard?
componenttext: Can you share any sort of customer feedback as to what kept actions a bit different than what you would have thought? Was it, I guess, the general range of comments around the economy and the product, or is there anything more specific you heard?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, nothing more specific. We've been selling in a tough economy here for 24 months. So I would say, it's nothing that we have not seen in the last two years of operating.
componenttext: Yes, nothing more specific. We've been selling in a tough economy here for 24 months. So I would say, it's nothing that we have not seen in the last two years of operating.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Certainly then just take us on the balance sheet, Steve, you talked about inventories up partly due to DCC. I would assume that's only $7 million or $8 million of that inventory boost sequentially. I don't know if that's right. So you're saying on a fair
componenttext: Certainly then just take us on the balance sheet, Steve, you talked about inventories up partly due to DCC. I would assume that's only $7 million or $8 million of that inventory boost sequentially. I don't know if that's right. So you're saying on a fair amount of the CEREC inventory, when do we see that coming? Do you just like seeing it come down here in the next quarter, or is that going to take two more quarters? And how much reduction are you hoping to get out of inventories?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: The acquisition impact, Larry, was about double what you mentioned. And then as far as working out the CEREC inventory, that is only dependent on the capabilities of our sales force, which we have great faith in. So it will happen, we think, very quickly.
componenttext: The acquisition impact, Larry, was about double what you mentioned. And then as far as working out the CEREC inventory, that is only dependent on the capabilities of our sales force, which we have great faith in. So it will happen, we think, very quickly.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And then just, Steve, I know last quarter, you talked about, I think, you alluded to $62 million of customer finance. The business that was in a roll off this quarter, that would've been a positive to cash flow. Obviously, that was somewhat offset by the
componenttext: And then just, Steve, I know last quarter, you talked about, I think, you alluded to $62 million of customer finance. The business that was in a roll off this quarter, that would've been a positive to cash flow. Obviously, that was somewhat offset by the boost in the inventory. But what else was in there that would have caused a negative year-over-year comp like in light of what I thought was going to be a good cash flow quarter?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Most of that, Larry, has to do with the liability side of our balance sheet. If you look at down the current liability section, you'll see that both payables and our accruals are down. And that's due to really the activity between the two years. So you've
componenttext: Most of that, Larry, has to do with the liability side of our balance sheet. If you look at down the current liability section, you'll see that both payables and our accruals are down. And that's due to really the activity between the two years. So you've got, last year, we were actually building in those two categories in the first quarter because of some timing and some activity. This year, we actually paid them down, so you kind of have sort of a double whammy. Most of it is in the payable side and accrual side. We had bonuses we paid off this year. We had, under the new commissioned program, we had commissioned holdback that was paid off. And then just due to the timing of the payables and the way all the weeks fell, your trade payables came down.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Two other quick things. Just to get you to really reflect again, Scott, on the consumables market environment, would you define the market to be currently flat, so you're basically growing at market? Is that how you're thinking of it? And isn't that a lit
componenttext: Two other quick things. Just to get you to really reflect again, Scott, on the consumables market environment, would you define the market to be currently flat, so you're basically growing at market? Is that how you're thinking of it? And isn't that a little bit worse than what you have thought three months ago?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I think we're going at or slightly above market when we look at all the data points between our manufacturer, partners and industry reports. And so our hope is that we were going to see some lift per consumer demand, but it was a fairly quiet sum
componenttext: Yes, and I think we're going at or slightly above market when we look at all the data points between our manufacturer, partners and industry reports. And so our hope is that we were going to see some lift per consumer demand, but it was a fairly quiet summer. And our hope that the second half of the year, we're going to see some lift. I would say, Larry, both from internal programs and from just general demand lift.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I know, Steve, you quantified exactly the benefit with the extra week. I think last quarter, you said, it would be about $0.02 to $0.04. Do we think of it as about a $0.03 benefit in EPS, or are you able to quantify that any more specifically?
componenttext: I know, Steve, you quantified exactly the benefit with the extra week. I think last quarter, you said, it would be about $0.02 to $0.04. Do we think of it as about a $0.03 benefit in EPS, or are you able to quantify that any more specifically?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: We've never really brought that down, Larry. I think we've talked about a $0.02 to $0.04 range and it's somewhere in that range. It's no more than $0.04 and probably no less than $0.02.
componenttext: We've never really brought that down, Larry. I think we've talked about a $0.02 to $0.04 range and it's somewhere in that range. It's no more than $0.04 and probably no less than $0.02.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And then just sort of sequentially, normal, your second quarter is a little bit higher than first. And I know you don't guide the quarters, but if you sort of back out let's just say the midpoint of that $0.03, is there any reason to think that the second
componenttext: And then just sort of sequentially, normal, your second quarter is a little bit higher than first. And I know you don't guide the quarters, but if you sort of back out let's just say the midpoint of that $0.03, is there any reason to think that the second quarter would actually be up or flat sequentially given you got the boost in the first quarter or is it too early to tell?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: As you had said, we don't give quarterly guidance anymore, but I think you're moving around the data point.
componenttext: As you had said, we don't give quarterly guidance anymore, but I think you're moving around the data point.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our next question does come from the line of Steven Valiquette with UBS.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our next question does come from the line of Steven Valiquette with UBS.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Say on the DCC acquisition, it seems like even with the integration cost that you mentioned, seems like it's still -- I'm having a hard time making that deal only be neutral to earnings for this year. So I'm wondering if either of the margin profile was a
componenttext: Say on the DCC acquisition, it seems like even with the integration cost that you mentioned, seems like it's still -- I'm having a hard time making that deal only be neutral to earnings for this year. So I'm wondering if either of the margin profile was a bit lower than in the overall Medical average? Or perhaps if you can just quantify what the integration costs are going to be from your point of view? I think it has to be something in the $5 million to $10 million range to have the deal only be neutral. So I just wanted to get a little more color around that.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Steve, this is Steve Armstrong. You hit on the point. It's really in the margins of the acquired business. They were quite a bit weaker than ours at the time we acquired that business. We think there's significant opportunity to improve them. We get them
componenttext: Steve, this is Steve Armstrong. You hit on the point. It's really in the margins of the acquired business. They were quite a bit weaker than ours at the time we acquired that business. We think there's significant opportunity to improve them. We get them up at least equal to our margins in our Medical business, but it's going to take some work, and part of that is the integration and the consolidation of the operation.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And then just all your comments on CEREC were helpful as well, but I think I missed it. What was the actual CEREC comp number in the quarter?

componenttext: As far as percentage is down?

componenttext: We're down in the mid-20.

componenttextpreview: And we were up 90% a year ago and we were down 20% to that in this quarter.
componenttext: And we were up 90% a year ago and we were down 20% to that in this quarter.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And our next question does come from the line of Bob Willoughby with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: And our next question does come from the line of Bob Willoughby with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

componenttext: Scott or Steve, it looks like nothing on the share repurchase front, not even anything to really offset the option creep. It looks like in the quarter, is the stock too rich for you here or what's the prognosis there?

componenttext: Perfect timing, Bob. We still have the acquisition capability. The repurchase authorization, we'll continue to use it.

componenttextpreview: Was there anything in the quarter that was done or...
componenttext: Was there anything in the quarter that was done or...

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: No. Not at this point.
componenttext: No. Not at this point.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I know at one point, Steve, you talked about possibly doing something on a more automated basis. Is that a possibility that we will see something every quarter? Or is it going to be much more opportunistic?
componenttext: I know at one point, Steve, you talked about possibly doing something on a more automated basis. Is that a possibility that we will see something every quarter? Or is it going to be much more opportunistic?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I think the answer to your question, Bob, is, yes, you'll probably see something more active as we go forward into 2011. Again, watching the cash balance and making sure we've got enough to do what we need to do if acquisitions materialize, I think has be
componenttext: I think the answer to your question, Bob, is, yes, you'll probably see something more active as we go forward into 2011. Again, watching the cash balance and making sure we've got enough to do what we need to do if acquisitions materialize, I think has been the priority. As we get deeper into the year, I think you could see us more active in the repurchase program.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010

componenttext: And the reason why maybe in the quarter nothing happened, despite some of those receivable sales, was it just that the deal itself took precedence or the CEREC build or were there other factors that kept you a bit more cautious?

componenttextpreview: No. It's just strictly the activity within the quarter and the timing within the quarter.
componenttext: No. It's just strictly the activity within the quarter and the timing within the quarter.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And our next question does come from the line of Derek Leckow with Barrington Research.
componenttext: And our next question does come from the line of Derek Leckow with Barrington Research.

componenttext: The comments around basic equipment, I mean, it was 13% total, what was the basic category up this quarter?
