componenttextpreview: We gave that 17%, Derek.
componenttext: We gave that 17%, Derek.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And then as far as any backlog, you did say last quarter that you had a bit of a backlog. Was this part of the backlog that was filled in the quarter? Or has the backlog continued to increase?
componenttext: And then as far as any backlog, you did say last quarter that you had a bit of a backlog. Was this part of the backlog that was filled in the quarter? Or has the backlog continued to increase?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we're seeing increased activity in backlog. We're not back to levels two and a half years ago, but in terms of backlog and incoming orders into our top manufacturers. And anecdotally, just pure activity from our equipment sales specialist th
componenttext: Well, I think we're seeing increased activity in backlog. We're not back to levels two and a half years ago, but in terms of backlog and incoming orders into our top manufacturers. And anecdotally, just pure activity from our equipment sales specialist that we monitor. We feel comfortable that we're definitely gaining ground on prior year and look to see improved equipment sales throughout the balance of the year.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And then just on the CEREC questions, I know a lot of these was discussed earlier. But it seems to me that when you talk to Sirona, you hear about their big promotional activities planned for this weekend. They got 2,000 doctors attending the show. Do you
componenttext: And then just on the CEREC questions, I know a lot of these was discussed earlier. But it seems to me that when you talk to Sirona, you hear about their big promotional activities planned for this weekend. They got 2,000 doctors attending the show. Do you think that there's been some deferral of orders as a result of that? And do you think there's anything to read into the strong GALILEO sales to say that perhaps, that's one part of a two-part system that they're selling. Do you think there was some deferral of CEREC as it relates to new users, especially around the show?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I wouldn't peg it on deferral, Derek. We're very excited about how successful the Las Vegas show is in terms of number of attendees, well over 2,000 doctors. A lot of those are current owners, which we think helps fuel GALILEO sales. But you're right
componenttext: Yes, I wouldn't peg it on deferral, Derek. We're very excited about how successful the Las Vegas show is in terms of number of attendees, well over 2,000 doctors. A lot of those are current owners, which we think helps fuel GALILEO sales. But you're right, it is a system, and that's one of the reasons why we are so committed to this long term as we think the Sirona technology and the technology of some of our other partners is really going to help change dentistry. And that's why we take a real long-term view on the CEREC product.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And is there anything signaling you in terms of your technical sales and service department , the -- you have nice increase in the total category. But I'm just wondering, are we seeing doctors kind of nurse along older chairs and units that are kind of we
componenttext: And is there anything signaling you in terms of your technical sales and service department , the -- you have nice increase in the total category. But I'm just wondering, are we seeing doctors kind of nurse along older chairs and units that are kind of wearing out? And is that why we're seeing an increase in some of those parts and labor sales?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Derek, I think that's definitely been a trend the last two years as dentists have been a little more cautious on their capital spend. And if they can fix something and particularly, the Chair business has been affected by that. And I think that just,
componenttext: Yes, Derek, I think that's definitely been a trend the last two years as dentists have been a little more cautious on their capital spend. And if they can fix something and particularly, the Chair business has been affected by that. And I think that just, to me, strengthens the value proposition that our sales people have in terms of how important the technical services to the overall relationship. But the dentist will not defer forever. We know that they're going to have to shield some taxes in the upcoming calendar fourth quarter. And we think we've got good programs and great products with our partners to gain more than our fair share of this pent-up demand.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: The last question is on the Medical side. You're getting to a nice critical mass now on a global basis and just wondered if you've identified any additional product categories that look good for in terms of a vertical integration opportunity?
componenttext: The last question is on the Medical side. You're getting to a nice critical mass now on a global basis and just wondered if you've identified any additional product categories that look good for in terms of a vertical integration opportunity?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we wouldn't disclose that. I would just echo that we really feel good about our Medical business in total. I was just at their national sales meeting this week. And we've got a fantastic group of sales people and a great management team and that busi
componenttext: Yes, we wouldn't disclose that. I would just echo that we really feel good about our Medical business in total. I was just at their national sales meeting this week. And we've got a fantastic group of sales people and a great management team and that business has a lot of momentum. And really, we feel is going to be a key growth driver for Patterson Companies for years to come.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen. Thank you for standing by. Welcome to Patterson Companies’ Q2 Earnings Conference Call. (Operator Instructions). This conference is being recorded today, Tuesday, November 23rd, 2010. I would now like to turn the conferen
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen. Thank you for standing by. Welcome to Patterson Companies’ Q2 Earnings Conference Call. (Operator Instructions). This conference is being recorded today, Tuesday, November 23rd, 2010. I would now like to turn the conference over to Scott Anderson, President and CEO. Please go ahead.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Alicia. Good morning, and thanks for participating in our Q2 earnings conference call. Joining me today is Steve Armstrong, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. At the conclusion of our formal remarks, Steve and I will be p
componenttext:
Thank you, Alicia. Good morning, and thanks for participating in our Q2 earnings conference call. Joining me today is Steve Armstrong, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. At the conclusion of our formal remarks, Steve and I will be pleased to take your questions.
Since Regulation FD prohibits us from providing investors with any earnings guidance unless we release that information simultaneously, we’ve provided financial guidance for fiscal 2011 in our press release earlier this morning. Our guidance is subject to a number of risks and uncertainties that could cause Patterson’s actual results to vary from our forecast. These risks and uncertainties are discussed in detail in our annual report and on Form 10K of our SEC filings, and we urge you to review this material.
Turning to our Q2 results, consolidated sales of $857.4 million were up 5% from $815 million in last year’s Q2. Internal growth generated one half of the sales increase, with acquisitions including currency exchange accounting for the balance. Net income of $53.4 million or $0.45 per diluted share rose 8%, from $49.3 million or $0.41 per diluted share in the Q2 of fiscal 2010. We are encouraged by Patterson’s solid Q2 results, which were attained amid the context of soft economic conditions that continued to affect our served markets.
Sales of Patterson Dental Supply increased 5% to $563.2 million in this year’s Q2. Sales of consumable dental supplies rose 1% from last year’s Q2, reflecting the impact of the economy upon patient demand for dental services. We believe the dental market has stabilized, and there could be a modest consumable market growth during the second half of our fiscal year.
For the quarter, our Equipment business grew 14% in response to our continuing initiatives aimed at emphasizing the productivity benefits and rapid rates of return of new technology equipment. Reflecting the effectiveness of these efforts, sales of CEREC dental restoration system increased nearly 30% in the Q2. The primary contributor of this growth was more than a 50% increase in new unit sales year over year. CEREC sales also benefited from a strong finish to the tradeoff program that began earlier this year.
For the full year, we continue to believe that CEREC sales should increase by at least 10% which would represent a very solid performance. In addition, sales of Schick digital sensors and our various lines of cone beam and panoramic imaging systems produced a very strong increase from year earlier levels, another indication of the effectiveness of our sales and marketing efforts.
Turning now to Patterson Medical, sales of rehabilitation supply and equipment unit increased 13% to $132.6 million in this year’s Q2, reflecting the positive impact of the June, 2010 acquisition of the rehabilitation business of DCC Healthcare. Q2 sales reflect the impact in the UK of budgetary constraints being imposed by the British government on its national health service. While austerity moves in the UK are expected to influence domestic sales there, the worldwide business continues to grow nicely. As such, we believe our rehabilitation business is increasingly well-positioned as an ongoing growth driver.
The previously reported acquisition of DCC rehabilitation business is of particular strategic importance to Patterson Medical. In addition to significantly strengthening and expanding Patterson Medical’s international presence, the acquired businesses bring a stable of trusted and established brand names that encompass an extensive range of products. The integration of the acquired units is proceeding on schedule, and expenses related to this activity should continue to gradually moderate over the next few quarters.
As we have stated previously, we are not anticipating a meaningful contribution to our earnings from this acquisition in fiscal 2011 after factoring in the costs of acquisition, integration, and the incremental amortization of intangible assets arising from the valuation process, however we expect the acquired businesses to be accretive to Patterson’s earnings in fiscal 2012.
Turning to Webster Veterinary, sales of our Veterinary unit increased slightly in this year’s Q2 to $161.6 million. We were pleased with Webster’s overall performance although the year over year comparability of Webster sales was affected by previously reported changes in the distribution arrangements for certain pharmaceuticals. We estimate that this changeover had the effect of reducing Webster’s Q2 sales growth by approximately 4 to 5 percentage points. Webster will continue to experience the impact of this sales mix on its sales for approximately one more quarter.
During this quarter we purchased and retired approximately 1.3 million shares of Patterson stock which, when combined with our quarterly dividend, returned approximately $50 million to shareholders during the period. We will continue to use our remaining repurchase authorization of approximately 4.5 million shares when we believe our cash position and market conditions justify it.
Regarding our financial outlook contained in this morning’s release, we are reiterating our previously issued guidance of $1.89 to $1.99 per diluted share for fiscal 2011. As we complete the first half of our year and look ahead to the second half, our fiscal year is unfolding in line with our initial expectations. We believe our dental, veterinary, and rehabilitation markets are gradually strengthening. These markets also have attracted long-term fundamentals and our three businesses are well positioned to capitalize upon these opportunities.
Moreover, we are generating strong operating cash flows, providing us with ample resources for supporting our various growth initiatives. These factors make us optimistic about Patterson’s future. Thank you. Now Steve Armstrong will review some operational highlights from our Q2 performance. Steve?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Scott. To begin I just have a couple of additional points on our sales performance for the quarter. On a consolidated basis, currency exchange had a favorable 20 basis point impact on sales growth. Within our Webster Veterinary segment, sales g
componenttext:
Thank you, Scott. To begin I just have a couple of additional points on our sales performance for the quarter. On a consolidated basis, currency exchange had a favorable 20 basis point impact on sales growth. Within our Webster Veterinary segment, sales growth was influenced by two negative factors in addition to the shift in mix towards agency sales in the flea & tick and heartworm categories that Scott mentioned. First, Webster sales were affected by our decision to exit the production animal business that was part of Clumbus Serem’s operations prior to its acquisition. This occurred primarily in the Q3 and the Q4 of fiscal 2010. And second, as a result of the various pharmaceutical mergers over the past two years, certain products previously sold through distribution are now being sold direct by the manufacturer. As we noted during previous conference calls, these factors are expected to generally dissipate in our third fiscal quarter.
Moving on to our consolidated gross margin, we saw a slight decrease of ten basis points from the prior year. Two factors that contributed to this decrease was a shift in our dental sales mix toward equipment and the impact of being unable to recognize gains from our finance contract sales. I will talk more about this latter item in a couple of minutes. The gross margins of the Veterinary and Medical segments both improved for the quarter as product mix and rebates favorably impacted the results of these segments. We improved our operating expense leverage in the quarter by 30 basis points despite absorbing the expenses relating to the integration of the acquired DCC rehabilitation assets. For the quarter, the Medical segment’s operating margin was reduced by over 100 basis points by the integration of the DCC assets but this should begin to improve as we move into the second half of the fiscal year. By segment, our Q2 operating margins were 11.3% for dental, 13.8% for medical, and 5.1% for veterinary.
As you may have noted in our press release this morning, we became aware late in the quarter that our customer financing agreement, whereby we sell the finance contracts to a commercial paper conduit, required modification for us to continue to remove the finance contracts from our financial statements when sold. While this was an unpleasant surprise, considering the due diligence that we had done to be certain that we complied with the new provisions of the relevant accounting standards, I want to emphasize that this does not change the underlying economics for the customer or Patterson.
We have nearly completed the technical modifications to our financing agreement which will bring it into compliance with the provisions of ASC-860, accounting for the transfers of financial assets, that allow us to remove the contracts from our financial statements as they are sold. We expect to close on the amended agreement in early December. In the meantime, the contracts that we sold during this year’s Q1 and Q2, which are the contracts impacted by the new provisions of ASC-860 are shown on our balance sheet as an asset and a liability. The gain connected with these sales has been deferred. In our statement of cash flows for the period, the sales of finance contracts is grossed up such that the cash flow from operations is reduced and the cash flow from financing activities is increased for the cash received on the sale of the contracts.
When the amended agreements are closed, our financial statements will reflect the activities of our customer financing activities consistent with our historical presentation. Again, the cash is on the balance sheet and is available for us to use.
Our balance sheet shows that inventory levels decreased by approximately $30 million during the quarter, as we wrapped up the CEREC trade up program and executed on our sales programs. The growth in inventory since the beginning of the fiscal year has resulted from the acquisition of the DCC assets during the Q1. Our DSO stands at 44 days in the current period, consistent with the prior year, while inventory turns are at 7 compared to 7.2 a year ago. The DSO for each period excludes the impact of finance contracts.
We generated cash flow from operations of approximately $86 million in the Q2, compared to $8 million in the year earlier period. The cash flow amount that I just provided for the current period adjusts for the impact of the gross up of our customer financing operations discussed earlier. Our CAPEX for the first half of the year includes the completion of the build out of our new distribution center in South Bend, Indiana, and the progress on a new facility for the Patterson Technology Center. It is our expectation that CAPEX for the fiscal year should be approximately $35 million.
With that, I’ll turn it back to the conference operator who will poll you for your questions. Alicia?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, sir. (Operator Instructions.) The first question is from the line of Lisa Gill with JP Morgan. Please go ahead.
componenttext: Thank you, sir. (Operator Instructions.) The first question is from the line of Lisa Gill with JP Morgan. Please go ahead.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of quick questions. One, Steve or Scott, can you give us any indication around the strength of the dental equipment market? Is it sustainable? Is this anything to do with the tax benefits that we’re seeing right now?
componenttext: Just a couple of quick questions. One, Steve or Scott, can you give us any indication around the strength of the dental equipment market? Is it sustainable? Is this anything to do with the tax benefits that we’re seeing right now?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hi Lisa, this is Scott. I think the tax benefits we see as a net positive and really a net positive looking out over the next 18 months. With the new Section 179 provisions our customers now can add lease hold improvements into that section which we think
componenttext: Hi Lisa, this is Scott. I think the tax benefits we see as a net positive and really a net positive looking out over the next 18 months. With the new Section 179 provisions our customers now can add lease hold improvements into that section which we think will help stimulate some renewed interest in office buildups and remodels, things that had been deferred the last two years. In terms of strength, on the technology side we do see that as sustainable and really look at this as part of what we’ve talked about for many years, this transition from film to digital and into new technology products like CEREC. So we do feel that’s sustainable and we appreciate the tax benefits.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: And what do you think the main driver of CEREC is right now? Is it the upgrade cycle that you’re currently going through? I know obviously the tax benefits you talked a little bit about, I mean are there other things that are out there in the dental env
componenttext: And what do you think the main driver of CEREC is right now? Is it the upgrade cycle that you’re currently going through? I know obviously the tax benefits you talked a little bit about, I mean are there other things that are out there in the dental environment that are driving people to a CEREC sale?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you’re starting to see the effect of having over 11,000 users in the market and the network of CEREC growing. In terms of promotions, we’ve always done promotions on CEREC. Another thing that we’ve really benefited from has been the in
componenttext: Well, I think you’re starting to see the effect of having over 11,000 users in the market and the network of CEREC growing. In terms of promotions, we’ve always done promotions on CEREC. Another thing that we’ve really benefited from has been the introduction of the Galileos cone beam machine and its integration with CEREC. I think the dental community is understanding that the CEREC story is a multifaceted story, not just a chair-side restoration story which is the bulk of the product line, in that digital dentistry is the future. And the fact that we still have six out of ten dentists using dental film says that there’s a long runway as we move the industry towards a digital platform.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just one question on that, the consumable side. If I compare you to your next biggest peer, it looks like they trended at about 150 basis points growth on the consumables side, and you came in at about 50 basis points. What are you seeing as far
componenttext: And then just one question on that, the consumable side. If I compare you to your next biggest peer, it looks like they trended at about 150 basis points growth on the consumables side, and you came in at about 50 basis points. What are you seeing as far as competitive dynamics in the marketplace?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think from all the data points we get from multiple manufacturers we feel we’re growing slightly above market on the consumables side, and obviously dramatically above market on the technology and equipment side. I think what we’re encouraged by as
componenttext: I think from all the data points we get from multiple manufacturers we feel we’re growing slightly above market on the consumables side, and obviously dramatically above market on the technology and equipment side. I think what we’re encouraged by as we look at the market and our customer base rather than our competitor, is we’ve seen stabilization. We’re starting to see some rolling 12 month averages on some key product categories that we carry starting to strengthen, and as I said in my opening comments we look for a gradual strengthening of the consumable markets. So I think we’re very comfortable with the position we’re at and think that they’ll be better underlying market dynamics in the next twelve, 24, 36 months for the dental space.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay great. Thank you.
componenttext: Okay great. Thank you.

componenttext: Thanks, Lisa.

componenttext: Hi, thanks very much. Just a follow-up to Lisa’s question about dental growth: the 14% you saw in equipment, how did that break down between the higher tech categories and basic?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our basic, our chair unit lines, our chair unit cabinetry lines, John, was down from prior year. As we said, CEREC was up over 30% and our digital platforms obviously were up substantially. And you know, I would just note that this was not an easy comp fo
componenttext: Our basic, our chair unit lines, our chair unit cabinetry lines, John, was down from prior year. As we said, CEREC was up over 30% and our digital platforms obviously were up substantially. And you know, I would just note that this was not an easy comp for our dental group either; we were up roughly 3% a year ago when most of the market was down double digits. So all things being said I think they executed well across all product lines.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Great, thanks. And as you look at your pipeline as we head into calendar year end how do you feel, and how does it compare to prior years?
componenttext: Great, thanks. And as you look at your pipeline as we head into calendar year end how do you feel, and how does it compare to prior years?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we’re still in an environment where our visibility isn’t as clear as what we could have said three, four, five years ago, but we’re encouraged by the tax changes in Sections 179 and 168. We know that a lot of projects have been deferre
componenttext: Well, I think we’re still in an environment where our visibility isn’t as clear as what we could have said three, four, five years ago, but we’re encouraged by the tax changes in Sections 179 and 168. We know that a lot of projects have been deferred, and as dentists gain confidence there’s definitely great incentives in front of them and access to capital to renew those projects, and our sales team is out here making sure that we get our lion’s share of those projects.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Great, thanks. And then just one other question, this one about the vet business. The 4% to 5% hit you mentioned by the shift to agency in the flea & tick category, what sort of an impact did that have at the operating income line if any?
componenttext: Great, thanks. And then just one other question, this one about the vet business. The 4% to 5% hit you mentioned by the shift to agency in the flea & tick category, what sort of an impact did that have at the operating income line if any?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: John, this is Steve. Generally that causes, in a ratio perspective it actually causes it to improve; dollars and cents, it has very little impact.
componenttext: John, this is Steve. Generally that causes, in a ratio perspective it actually causes it to improve; dollars and cents, it has very little impact.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Great, okay. So it hurts you on the top line but on the bottom line it really did not have an impact.
componenttext: Great, okay. So it hurts you on the top line but on the bottom line it really did not have an impact.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: It’s pretty much neutral work. We actually went back and again, this quarter like we did last quarter, we looked at not only the revenue mix - we also looked at what’s happening with doses. And we know doses going out the door is continuing to grow so
componenttext: It’s pretty much neutral work. We actually went back and again, this quarter like we did last quarter, we looked at not only the revenue mix - we also looked at what’s happening with doses. And we know doses going out the door is continuing to grow so we’re putting more dollars on the operating line. And it does as well when you have that agency increase in your revenue line, you do get some better metrics but mostly what we’re paying attention to is doses out the door.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: So what do you think is really happening here? Are you adding new customers, tapping into the married off lines that you didn’t have before? Are you seeing conversions of customers that were previously buying other brands that are switching?
componenttext: So what do you think is really happening here? Are you adding new customers, tapping into the married off lines that you didn’t have before? Are you seeing conversions of customers that were previously buying other brands that are switching?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, and I’ll answer this first and let Scott jump in here. I think you’re seeing a combination of all of that, John. We’re getting some of the married out business back that we might have had leak off to competitors when we weren’t carr
componenttext: Well, I think, and I’ll answer this first and let Scott jump in here. I think you’re seeing a combination of all of that, John. We’re getting some of the married out business back that we might have had leak off to competitors when we weren’t carrying those lines. There’s obviously customer preferences; we want to make sure the customer has choices and so we have the products available to them. But the dosages are increasing, so we’ve got to be getting something from someone.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Great, thanks very much.
componenttext: Great, thanks very much.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Just on the Section 179 provisions as they relate to lease hold improvements, I’m just curious if you think we’re going to see this manifest itself in sort of a higher touch sales activity ahead of ultimately these orders being filled an
componenttext: Good morning. Just on the Section 179 provisions as they relate to lease hold improvements, I’m just curious if you think we’re going to see this manifest itself in sort of a higher touch sales activity ahead of ultimately these orders being filled and installed. I mean is it going to require a lot more consultative work with your dental customers to get those deals closed?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, Derek, and I would say again one of our strengths is we’ve always had a very high touch, consultative relationship with our customers, so we just see the beefing up of the tax benefits as a net positive for the customer. Part of what we’re doing,
componenttext: No, Derek, and I would say again one of our strengths is we’ve always had a very high touch, consultative relationship with our customers, so we just see the beefing up of the tax benefits as a net positive for the customer. Part of what we’re doing, and we’re very aggressively marketing that, is to make sure the customer base in all three businesses know about the changes and sit down with their tax advisors so they’re completely informed when they start laying out their decisions. And as we talked about before, a lot of projects were ready to go and in the fall of 2008 were stopped because of uncertainty. So it’s our job to get those projects rolling again.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: And you had mentioned that your order book was starting to grow last quarter. Just wondered, you also mentioned today that your visibility still isn’t where you’d like it to be. But is your visibility better than it was say six to twelve months ago?
componenttext: And you had mentioned that your order book was starting to grow last quarter. Just wondered, you also mentioned today that your visibility still isn’t where you’d like it to be. But is your visibility better than it was say six to twelve months ago?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yeah, I would say definitely it’s better than it was six to twelve months ago, and hopefully it’s never again like it was six to twelve months ago.
componenttext: Yeah, I would say definitely it’s better than it was six to twelve months ago, and hopefully it’s never again like it was six to twelve months ago.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Alright, good. And just on the veterinary margins, I wonder if you’re anticipating a period of time during which the vet margins can improve? And what is it going to take to improve the margins in that business?
componenttext: Alright, good. And just on the veterinary margins, I wonder if you’re anticipating a period of time during which the vet margins can improve? And what is it going to take to improve the margins in that business?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think what it’s going to take to improve the margins is building out the value added platform, very similar to what Patterson’s philosophy is on taking care of the customers. So there are opportunities outside of pharmaceuticals in terms of so
componenttext: Well, I think what it’s going to take to improve the margins is building out the value added platform, very similar to what Patterson’s philosophy is on taking care of the customers. So there are opportunities outside of pharmaceuticals in terms of software and equipment and service - those are all areas that over time we need to execute on to build out a business that has sustainable expanding operating margins.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: And where do you see those operating margins going?
componenttext: And where do you see those operating margins going?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think over the coming years they can get up into the high single digits, and then it’s just a matter of driving profitable revenue from there. But there’s still a lot of work to be done. It’s a different marketplace than dental, so it’s not goin
componenttext: I think over the coming years they can get up into the high single digits, and then it’s just a matter of driving profitable revenue from there. But there’s still a lot of work to be done. It’s a different marketplace than dental, so it’s not going to happen overnight.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010

componenttext: And are you still adding personnel there? Is that something that’s going on with new branch offices? Or what’s happening with regards to the branch offices?

componenttext: The footprint is fairly well established with Webster, particularly after we did the Columbus Serum acquisition that really gave us strength in that Ohio Valley region. But adding sales reps and expanding geography is definitely in the playbook of Webster.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks for the questions. I just wanted to move over to the medical business. On the budgetary constraints being imposed by the UK government, can you elaborate a little bit on the nature of these cuts? Is it lower reimbursement on specific therapies
componenttext: Yes, thanks for the questions. I just wanted to move over to the medical business. On the budgetary constraints being imposed by the UK government, can you elaborate a little bit on the nature of these cuts? Is it lower reimbursement on specific therapies? And then I guess just beyond the UK, are you seeing or do you have any expectation that we could see some budgetary constraints in other relevant countries such as France?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we have seen the initial softness driven by the austerity measures. Really the softness in our medical business came from that. It also came from we saw tighter school budgets during the football bidding season that impacted sales at MedCo, our spor
componenttext: Well, we have seen the initial softness driven by the austerity measures. Really the softness in our medical business came from that. It also came from we saw tighter school budgets during the football bidding season that impacted sales at MedCo, our sports medicine business. While the top line was affected the MedCo management team did a great job with the product mix to protect the bottom line results. In addition at medical we made the strategic decision to exit some businesses from our Mobilis acquisition. I would say we’ll react to market conditions. We think going forward our strength in these markets, the UK and France, really gives us an opportunity to gain market share regardless of the market conditions. I would say, and Steve mentioned it in his comments, our international dealer business was very strong in the quarter, growing double digits. So I think it’s too early to tell in terms of the crystal ball on the austerity measures.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, that’s helpful. And then I guess just given the EPS to date and the maintained guidance implying a better back half, can you just maybe qualitatively talk a little bit about is this more market driven from where you sit or is it related a lot to s
componenttext: Okay, that’s helpful. And then I guess just given the EPS to date and the maintained guidance implying a better back half, can you just maybe qualitatively talk a little bit about is this more market driven from where you sit or is it related a lot to seasonality? If you could just maybe give us a sense of that. And then as we’ve moved from last quarter into this quarter, can you give us a sense of the progression you’re seeing month to month in dental visits?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: It’s Steve. I’ll talk first about the guidance and then I’ll follow up with the dental visits. Yeah, I think going back to the essence of your question, there is some seasonality. The last half of Patterson’s year is generally a more productive ye
componenttext: It’s Steve. I’ll talk first about the guidance and then I’ll follow up with the dental visits. Yeah, I think going back to the essence of your question, there is some seasonality. The last half of Patterson’s year is generally a more productive year. We have more capital activity during that cycle and there seems to be more dentistry performed during the winter months as sort of licensed consistent people, or the kids are in school and a lot of vacations either of staff or of patients. So you do see higher performance in the Q3 and the Q4 out of our business. With that said, I would tell you that the Q3 for the vet business happens to be their lowest production quarter. As the northern tier states freeze up, you’ve got less mosquitoes obviously, less heartworm, less flea & tick; and then as you get into the Q4 the vets start stocking back up again. So with regard to the guidance, we’re obviously continuing to be cautious. It’s a soft market out there as Scott mentioned and so we have to be cautious, but at the same time we’re optimistic. Our organizations across the board are doing the (inaudible) job to generate revenues when the customers aren’t jumping out of the woods to grab the product out of your hands.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: And I would just follow up on visits, we still see the similar trends in terms of we look at products tied to hygiene visits, and they still continue to grow at a faster pace than the restorative products. So our theory is, and we feel confident in this,
componenttext: And I would just follow up on visits, we still see the similar trends in terms of we look at products tied to hygiene visits, and they still continue to grow at a faster pace than the restorative products. So our theory is, and we feel confident in this, that the hygiene chairs are still full in the dental offices, and the challenge continues to be moving people over for restorative work and discretionary procedures. So the two big things we look at obviously, and we’ve talked about this many times, is consumer confidence and unemployment. And we think as those two gradually improve you’ll see the underlying market firm up even more. That being said, a lot of our customers have been very proactive in how they move people through their offices and schedule to increase productivity, and I think the reason technology products have resonated so well in this time of flat market growth is that dentists really are looking at ways that they can treat their patients more efficiently and also have a much better patient experience. And products like digital x-ray and CEREC surely increase the patient experience in the dental office.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: That’s helpful. Thanks for the comments.
componenttext: That’s helpful. Thanks for the comments.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, thank you. Congratulations on a decent quarter there. I was curious on the international margins if you can go over that a little bit. Obviously you have some integration costs here currently, but how do you envision the international margins or wher
componenttext: Yes, thank you. Congratulations on a decent quarter there. I was curious on the international margins if you can go over that a little bit. Obviously you have some integration costs here currently, but how do you envision the international margins or where they should go over time?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we’ve never really broken out our international business and our international margins. It’s different by unit. I would tell you that the international margins in the medical business we would expect to improve. Obviously right now they’re bei
componenttext: Well, we’ve never really broken out our international business and our international margins. It’s different by unit. I would tell you that the international margins in the medical business we would expect to improve. Obviously right now they’re being impacted by the, to some degree even by the residuals of the Mobilis acquisition that we did a year and a half ago, but also by the acquisition of the DCC Healthcare properties that we did earlier this year. And so we’re still I think predicting and expecting that the operating margins for the medical business in total will move up into the mid to high teens as we go forward. They have to continue to make investments in their business. We’re going to allow them to do that, which will use up some of that potential margin expansion going forward. But over time we expect those margins up in the high teens.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And you talked a little bit about the finance contracts and then mentioned the deferred gains. How should we think about that, the deferred gains on those contracts as we progress through the remainder of this fiscal year?
componenttext: Okay. And you talked a little bit about the finance contracts and then mentioned the deferred gains. How should we think about that, the deferred gains on those contracts as we progress through the remainder of this fiscal year?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, with a great deal of certainty I will tell you that we expect that those gains will be reestablished in the Q3. There’s no absolute certainty because we still have to finalize the contract amendments that we’re working on, but those are nearly d
componenttext: Well, with a great deal of certainty I will tell you that we expect that those gains will be reestablished in the Q3. There’s no absolute certainty because we still have to finalize the contract amendments that we’re working on, but those are nearly done, agreed to in principle in all fashions. They’ve been through the lawyer abuse and so forth. So I think what you’re going to see, Richard, is we’ll get those gains back very quickly here in the Q3 as we sign those new agreements.

componenttext: Well in the other you’ve got a combination of interest income and interest expense. We wouldn’t expect a lot of change in the interest expense debt to stabilize. Interest income, as we sell off these contracts completely now and get them off our balance sheet some of that interest income that we record on those contracts while we carry them will be replaced by the gains. And then in the other category you’ve got some assets expense in there this year; I think it was actually a gain last year. And then you may recall that we invested in a group called Vet Source who has a home delivery capability and pharmacy management operation for the vet office/clinic. And we have that on an equity investment - we have about a 30% interest in that business and so we had to pick up their operations under the accounting rules in that other category under equity accounting.

componenttext: I think it still is just market conditions. I would say six months through the year we feel we’re right on plan. componenttext: Well, we don’t comment obviously, A. J., specifically on acquisitions, but we feel that we are a great strategic acquirer. Most of our acquisitions are relationship based and come around timing of family owned businesses. We also will pay fair value for businesses even in times like this so we see our position in terms of capital allocation, that’s one of our strategies. If the right businesses come up for acquisition we definitely will be a player.

componenttext: Well I think, Jeff, it all comes down to execution. We try not to concentrate on the comps internally. headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen. Thank you for standing by. Welcome to Patterson Companies Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] This conference is being recorded today, Tuesday, November 23, 2010. I would now like to turn the
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen. Thank you for standing by. Welcome to Patterson Companies Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] This conference is being recorded today, Tuesday, November 23, 2010. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to Scott Anderson, President and CEO. Please go ahead.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Alicia. Good morning and thanks for participating in our second quarter earnings conference call. Joining me today is Steve Armstrong, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. At the conclusion of our formal remarks, Steve and
componenttext:
Thank you, Alicia. Good morning and thanks for participating in our second quarter earnings conference call. Joining me today is Steve Armstrong, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. At the conclusion of our formal remarks, Steve and I will be pleased to take your questions.
Since Regulation FD prohibits us from providing investors with any earnings guidance unless we release that information simultaneously, we’ve provided financial guidance for fiscal 2011 in our press release earlier this morning. Our guidance is subject to a number of risks and uncertainties that could cause Patterson’s actual results to vary from our forecast. These risks and uncertainties are discussed in detail in our annual report and on Form 10K of our SEC filings, and we urge you to review this material.
Turning to our second quarter results. Consolidated sales of $857.4 million were up 5% from $815 million last year's second quarter. Internal growth generated 1/2 of the sales increase with acquisitions and currency exchange accounting for the balance. 
Net income of $53.4 million or $0.45 per diluted share rose 8% from $49.3 million or $0.41 per diluted share in the second quarter of fiscal 2010. 
We are encouraged by Patterson's solid second quarter results, which were attained amid the context of soft economic conditions that continued to affect our served market. 
Sales of Patterson Dental Supply increased 5% to $563.2 million in this year's second quarter. Sales of consumable dental supplies rose 1% from last year's second quarter, reflecting the impact of the economy upon patient demand for dental services. 
We believe the dental market have stabilized and there could be a modest consumable market growth during the second half of our fiscal year. 
For the quarter, our Equipment business grew 14% in response to our continuing initiatives aimed at emphasizing the productivity benefits and rapid rates of return of new technology equipment. 
Reflecting the effectiveness of these efforts, sales of CEREC dental restoration system increased nearly 30% in the second quarter. The primary contributor of this growth was more than a 50% increase in new unit sales year-over-year . CEREC sales also benefited from a strong finish to the trade up program that began earlier this year. For the full year, we continue to believe that CEREC sales should increase by at least 10%, which would represent a very solid performance. 
In addition, sales of Schick digital sensors and our various lines of cone beam and panoramic imaging system produced a very strong increase from the year earlier level, another indication of the effectiveness of our sales and marketing efforts. 
Turning now to Patterson Medical. Sales of rehabilitation supply and equipment unit increased 13% to $132.6 million in this year's second quarter, reflecting the positive impact of the June 2010 acquisition of the rehabilitation business at DCC Healthcare. 
Second quarter sales reflect the impact in the U.K. of budgetary constraints being imposed by the British government on its National Health Service. While in the U.K. are expected to influence domestic sales there, the worldwide business continued to grow nicely. As such, we believe our rehabilitation business is increasingly well-positioned as an our ongoing growth driver.
The previously reported acquisition of DCC Rehabilitation business is of particular strategic importance to Patterson Medical. In addition to significantly strengthening and expanding Patterson Medical international presence, the acquired businesses bring a stable of trusted and established brand names that encompass an extensive range of products. The integration of the acquired units is proceeding on schedule and expenses related to this activity should continue to gradually moderate over the next few quarters.  As we have stated previously, we are not anticipating a meaningful contribution to our earnings from this acquisition in fiscal 2011. After factoring in the cost of acquisition, immigration and the incremental amortization of intangible assets arising from the evaluation process. However, we expect the acquired businesses to be accretive to Patterson's earnings in fiscal 2012. 
Turning to Webster Veterinary. Sales of our veterinary unit increased slightly in this year's second quarter to $161.6 million. We were pleased with Webster's overall performance, although the year-over-year comparability of Webster sales was affected by previously reported changes in the distribution arrangements for certain pharmaceuticals. We estimate that this change over had the effect of reducing Webster second quarter sales growth by approximately 4 to 5 percentage points. Webster will continue to experience the impact of the sales mix on its sales for approximately one more quarter. 
During this quarter, we purchased and retired approximately 1.3 million shares of Patterson's stock, which when combined with our quarterly dividends, returned approximately $50 million to shareholders during the period. We will continue to use our remaining repurchase authorization of approximately 4.5 million shares when we believe our cash position and market conditions justify it. 
Regarding our financial outlook contained in this morning's release, we are reiterating our previously issued guidance of $1.89 to $1.99 per diluted share for fiscal 2011. 
As we complete the first half of our year and look ahead to the second half, our fiscal year is unfolding in line with our initial expectations. We believe our dental, veterinary and rehabilitation markets are gradually strengthening. These markets also have attracted long-term fundamentals and our 3 businesses are well-positioned to capitalize upon these opportunities. Moreover, we are generating strong operating cash flows, providing us with ample resources for supporting our various growth initiatives. These factors make us optimistic about Patterson's future. 
Thank you. Now, Steve Armstrong will review some operational highlights for our second quarter performance. Steve?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Scott. To begin, I just have a couple of additional points on our sales performance for the quarter. On a consolidated basis, currency exchange had a favorable 20 basis point impact on sales growth. Within our Webster Veterinary segment, sales
componenttext:
Thank you, Scott. To begin, I just have a couple of additional points on our sales performance for the quarter. On a consolidated basis, currency exchange had a favorable 20 basis point impact on sales growth. Within our Webster Veterinary segment, sales growth was influenced by 2 negative factors in addition to the shift in mix toward agency sales in the flea and tick take heartworm categories as Scott mentioned. 
First, Webster sales were affected by our decision to exit the production animal business as part of the Columbus Serem operations prior to its acquisition. This occurred primarily in the third and fourth quarter of fiscal 2010. And second, as a result of the various pharmaceutical mergers over the past 2 years, certain products previously sold through distributions are now being sold direct by the manufacturer. As we noted during previous conference calls, these factors are expected to generally dissipate in our third fiscal quarter. 
Moving on to our consolidated gross margin. We saw slight decrease of 10 basis points from the prior year. Two factors contributed to this decrease with a shift in our dental sales mix towards equipment and the impact of being unable to recognize gains from our finance contract sales. I will talk more about this latter item in a couple of minutes. 
The gross margins of the Veterinary and Medical segments both improved for the quarter as product mix and rebates favorably impacted the result of these segments. We improved our operating expense leverage in the quarter by 30 basis points despite absorbing the expenses related to the integration of the acquired DCC Rehabilitation asset. 
For the quarter, the medical segment operating margin was reduced by over 100 basis points by the integration of the DCC asset. But this should begin to improve as we move into the second half of the fiscal year. 
By segment, our first quarter operating margins were 11.3% for dental, 13.8% for medical and 5.1% for veterinary. 
As you may have noted in our press release this morning, we became aware late in the quarter there are customer financing agreement or contracts would have commercial paper conduit required modification for us to continue to finance contracts from our financial statements when sold. While this was an unpleasant surprise considering the due diligence that we have done to be certain that we comply with the new provisions of the relevant accounting standards, I want to emphasize that it does not change the underlying economics for the customer or Patterson. 
We have nearly completed the technical modifications to our financing agreement, which will bring compliance with the provisions of the ASC-860 accounted for the transfer of the financial assets that will allow us to remove the contracts from our financial statements as they are sold. We expect to close the amended agreement in early December. 
In the meantime, the contracts that we sold during the year's first and second quarters, which are the contract impacted by the ASC-860, are shown on our balance sheet as an asset and a liability. A gain connected with the sales has been deferred. 
In our statement of cash flows for the period, the sales of finance contracts has gross up such as the cash flow from operations is reduced and the cash flow from financing activities is increased for the cash receipt in the sale of the contract. 
When the amended agreements are close, our financial statements will reflect the activities of our customer financing committee consistent with our historical presentation. Again, the cash is on the balance sheet and is available for us to use. 
Our balance sheet shows inventory levels increased by approximately $30 million during the quarter as planned as we wrap up as your trading program and executed on our sales program. 
The growth in inventory since the beginning of the fiscal year has resulted from teh acquisition of the DCC asset during the first quarter. 
Our DSO stands at 44 days in the current period consistent with the prior year, while inventory turns are 7x compared to 7.2x a year ago. The DSO for each period excludes the impact of finance contracts. 
We generated cash flow from operations of approximately $86 million in the second quarter compared to $8 million in the year-earlier period. The cash flow amount that I just provided for the current period adjusts for the impact of the growth of customer financing operations discussed earlier. 
Our CapEx for the first half of the year includes the completion of the buildup of our new distribution center at Southern Indiana and the progress of the new facility for the Patterson Technology Center. It is our expectation that CapEx for the fiscal year should be approximately $35 million. 
With that, I'll turn it back to the conference operator, who will poll you for your questions. Alicia?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question is from the line of Lisa Gill with JP Morgan.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question is from the line of Lisa Gill with JP Morgan.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of quick questions. One is, Steve or Scott, can you give us any indication around the strength of the dental equipment market? Is it sustainable? Does it have anything to do with the tax benefits that we're seeing right now?
componenttext: Just a couple of quick questions. One is, Steve or Scott, can you give us any indication around the strength of the dental equipment market? Is it sustainable? Does it have anything to do with the tax benefits that we're seeing right now?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Lisa, this is Scott. I think the tax benefits we see as a net positive and really a net positive looking out over the next 18 months with the new Section 179 provisions where customers now can at least hold improvements into that section, which we think w
componenttext: Lisa, this is Scott. I think the tax benefits we see as a net positive and really a net positive looking out over the next 18 months with the new Section 179 provisions where customers now can at least hold improvements into that section, which we think will help stimulate some renewed interest in office build outs and remodels, things that have been deferred the last few years. In terms of strength on the technology side, we do see that as sustainable and really look at this as part of what we've talked about for many years this transition from film to digital and into the new technology products like CEREC. So we do feel that's sustainable, and we appreciate the tax benefits.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: What do you think the main driver of CEREC is right now? Is it that the upgrade cycle that you're currently going through? I know that -- obviously the tax benefits -- you talked a little bit about -- I mean, are there other things that are out there in t
componenttext: What do you think the main driver of CEREC is right now? Is it that the upgrade cycle that you're currently going through? I know that -- obviously the tax benefits -- you talked a little bit about -- I mean, are there other things that are out there in the dental environment that are driving people to a CEREC sale?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well I think you're starting to see the effect of having over 11,000 users in the market and network of CEREC growing. In terms of promotions, we've always done promotions on CEREC. Another thing that we really benefited from has been the introduction of
componenttext: Well I think you're starting to see the effect of having over 11,000 users in the market and network of CEREC growing. In terms of promotions, we've always done promotions on CEREC. Another thing that we really benefited from has been the introduction of the Galileo's cone beam machine and its integration with CEREC. And I think the dental community is understanding that the CEREC story is a multi-faceted story, not just a restoration story, which is the bulk of the product line, and that digital dentistry is the future. The fact that we still have dentists using dental film says that there's a long runway as we move the industry towards a digital platform.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just one question on the consumable side. If I compare you to your next biggest peer, it looks like they trended about 150 basis points growth on the consumable side and you came in at about 50 basis points. What are you seeing as far as competit
componenttext: And then just one question on the consumable side. If I compare you to your next biggest peer, it looks like they trended about 150 basis points growth on the consumable side and you came in at about 50 basis points. What are you seeing as far as competitive dynamics in the marketplace?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think from all the data points we get from multiple manufacturers, we feel we're growing slightly above market on the consumable side and obviously Dramatically above market on the technology and equipment side. I think we're encouraged by -- as we look
componenttext: I think from all the data points we get from multiple manufacturers, we feel we're growing slightly above market on the consumable side and obviously Dramatically above market on the technology and equipment side. I think we're encouraged by -- as we look at market and our customer base rather than our competitor is we've seen stabilization. We're starting to see some rolling 12 month average is on some key product categories that we carry starting to strengthen. And as I said my opening comments we look for just gradual strengthening of the consumable market. So I think we are very comfortable with the position we're at and think that we'll have better underlying market dynamics in the next 12, 24, 36 months for the dental space.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010

componenttextpreview: Our basic line share unit cabinets, John, was down just slightly from prior year. As we said, CEREC was up over 30% and our digital platforms obviously were up substantially. I would just note that this was not an easy comp for our dental group. We were u
componenttext: Our basic line share unit cabinets, John, was down just slightly from prior year. As we said, CEREC was up over 30% and our digital platforms obviously were up substantially. I would just note that this was not an easy comp for our dental group. We were up roughly 3% a year ago, when most of the market was down double digits. So all things being said, I think they executed well across all product lines.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we're still in an environment where our visibility isn't as clear as what we could have said 3, 4, 5 years ago. But we are encouraged by the tax changes in Section 179 and 168. We know that a lot of projects have been deferred and the dentis
componenttext: Well, I think we're still in an environment where our visibility isn't as clear as what we could have said 3, 4, 5 years ago. But we are encouraged by the tax changes in Section 179 and 168. We know that a lot of projects have been deferred and the dentists gain confidence there's definitely great incentives in front of them and access to capital to renew those projects and our sales team is out there, making sure that we get our lion's share of those projects.

componenttext: Well, I think you're seeing a combination of all of that, John. We're getting some of the Merial business back that we might have had a week off to competitors when we weren't line. componenttext: Just on the 179 provision as they relate to improvements, I'm just curious if you think we're going to see this manifest itself in sort of a higher touch sales activity ahead of ultimately these orders being filled and installed? Is it going to require a lot more consultative work with your dental customers to get those deals closed?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: No. I would say one of our strength is we've always had a very high touch relationship with our customers. So we just see the beefing up of the tax benefit as a net positive for the customer. Part of what we're doing very aggressively marketing that is to
componenttext: No. I would say one of our strength is we've always had a very high touch relationship with our customers. So we just see the beefing up of the tax benefit as a net positive for the customer. Part of what we're doing very aggressively marketing that is to make sure the customer base in all 3 businesses know about the changes and sit down with your tax advisor is so they are completely informed when they start playing out their decisions and. As we've talked about before, a lot of projects were ready to go in the fall of 2008 were stopped because of uncertainty. So it's our job to get those projects rolling again.

componenttext: Well, I think it's going to take to improve the margin is building the value platform very similar to what Patterson's philosophy is on taking care of the customers. So our opportunities outside pharmaceuticals in terms of software and equipment and service, those are all areas that overtime we need to execute on to build out a business that has a sustainable operating margins.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to move over to medical business. On the budgetary constraint being imposed by the U.K. government, can you elaborate a little bit on the nature of these cuts? Is it lower reimbursement on specific therapies? And then I guess just beyond the U
componenttext: Just wanted to move over to medical business. On the budgetary constraint being imposed by the U.K. government, can you elaborate a little bit on the nature of these cuts? Is it lower reimbursement on specific therapies? And then I guess just beyond the U.K, are you seeing or do you have any expectation that we could see some budgetary constraints in other relevant countries such as France?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we have seen the initial softness driven by the austerity measures. Really the softness in our medical business came from that. It also came from a we saw a tighter school budget during football bidding season that impacted sales at Medco, our sport
componenttext: Well, we have seen the initial softness driven by the austerity measures. Really the softness in our medical business came from that. It also came from a we saw a tighter school budget during football bidding season that impacted sales at Medco, our sports medicine business. While the top line has affected Medco management team product mix to protect the bottom line results. In addition, at medical we made a strategic decision to exit some businesses from our Mobilis acquisitions. So I would say we'll react to market conditions. We think going forward our strength in these markets, U.K. and France, really gives us an opportunity to gain market share regardless of the market condition. I would say and Steve mentioned in his comments, our international dealer business was very strong in the quarter, growing double digits. So I think it's too early to tell in terms of the crystal ball on the measures.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess just given the EPS to-date and the maintained guidance, implying a better back half, can you just maybe qualitatively talk a little bit about it? Is it more market driven from where you sit or is it related a lot of seasonality? If you could just
componenttext: I guess just given the EPS to-date and the maintained guidance, implying a better back half, can you just maybe qualitatively talk a little bit about it? Is it more market driven from where you sit or is it related a lot of seasonality? If you could just maybe give us a sense of that. And then as we've moved from last quarter to this quarter, can you give us a sense of the progression you're seeing month-to-month in dental visits?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Steve will talk about first about the guidance and then I'll follow up on dental visits.
componenttext: Well, Steve will talk about first about the guidance and then I'll follow up on dental visits.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think going back to the essence of your question, there is some seasonality. The last half of Patterson year is generally a more productive year. We have more capital activity during that cycle. And there seems to be more dentistry performed during the
componenttext: I think going back to the essence of your question, there is some seasonality. The last half of Patterson year is generally a more productive year. We have more capital activity during that cycle. And there seems to be more dentistry performed during the winter months as sort of license consistent people or the kids are in school and staffed or outpatient. So you do see higher performance in the third and fourth quarter on our business. With that said, I would tell you that the third quarter for business happens to be their lowest production quarter as the northern mosquitoes obviously less flea and tick into the fourth quarter of the backup again. So with regard to the guidance, we are obviously continuing to be cautious. It's a soft market up there, as Scott mentioned. And so we have to be cautious. But at the same time we are optimistic our organizations across the board are doing job to generate revenues when the customers aren't jumping out of the woods to grab the product out of your hat.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: And I will just follow up on visits. We still see the similar trends in terms of we look at products hygiene visits and they still continued to grow faster pace than products. So our theory is and we feel confident that the hygiene shares are challenge co
componenttext: And I will just follow up on visits. We still see the similar trends in terms of we look at products hygiene visits and they still continued to grow faster pace than products. So our theory is and we feel confident that the hygiene shares are challenge continues to be moving people over for restorative work and discretionary procedures. So the 2 big things we look at obviously when we talk about this many times as consumer confidence and unemployment and we think as those two gradually improve as the underlying market firm up even more. That being said, a lot of our customers have been very proactive in how they move people through their offices and schedules in increased productivity and I think the reason technology products have resonated so well in this time of flat market growth is the dentist looking at ways that they can treat their patients more efficiently and also have a much better patient experience in products like digital x-ray and CEREC increase the patient experience in a dental office.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm curious on the international margins, if you can go over there a little bit. Obviously you have some integration costs here currently. But how do you envision the international margins where they should go over time?
componenttext: I'm curious on the international margins, if you can go over there a little bit. Obviously you have some integration costs here currently. But how do you envision the international margins where they should go over time?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we've never really broken out our international business and our international margins. It's different by unit. I would tell you that the international margins in the medical business we would expect to improve. Obviously right now they're being imp
componenttext: Well, we've never really broken out our international business and our international margins. It's different by unit. I would tell you that the international margins in the medical business we would expect to improve. Obviously right now they're being impacted to some degree even by the Mobilis acquisition that we got a year and a half ago but also by the acquisition of the DCC Healthcare properties that we did earlier this year. And so we're still I think predicting and expecting that to the operating margins for the medical business in total will move up into the mid- to high teen as we go forward. We have to continue to make investments in their business. We're going to allow them to do that, which will use up some of that potential margin expansion. But over time we expect those margins up in the high teens.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010

componenttext: Well, with a great deal of certainty I would tell you that we would expect that those gains would be reestablished in the third quarter. There's no absolute certainty because we still have to finalize the contract amendment that we're working on. But those are nearly done, agreed to in all fashion. They've been through the lawyer so forth. So I figure what you're going to see, Richard, is we'll get those gains back very quickly here in the third quarter as we sign those new agreements.

componenttext: Well, in the other -- you've got a combination of interest income and interest expense. We wouldn't expect a lot of change in the interest expense that stabilized interest income as we sell off these contracts completely now we get them off our balance sheet. Some of that interest income we recorded in those contracts when we carry them will be replaced by the gain. And then in the other category you've got some FX expansion there this year. I think it was actually a gain last year. And then you may recall that we invested in a group called Vet Source that is a home delivery capability and pharmacy management opportunity for the vet office clinic. And we have that on the equity investment. We have about 30 percentage in that business. And so we had to pick up their operations under the accounting rules in that other category under equity accounting.

componenttext: I think it still is just market conditions. I would say 6 months through the year we feel we are right on plan. We obviously have some momentum in all of our businesses. But we're still competing on a playing field with limited growth across all 3 businesses in terms of market growth. So we're just, I would say we're just being cautious and -- but we're still very optimistic about how we can finish the second half of the year.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: One question on that number, Scott. I guess as I look at the next few quarters, the CapEx a lot easier than this 45% comp you guys came up against this quarter. But the year-over-year growth numbers aren't always the best way to look at those comps, I rea
componenttext: One question on that number, Scott. I guess as I look at the next few quarters, the CapEx a lot easier than this 45% comp you guys came up against this quarter. But the year-over-year growth numbers aren't always the best way to look at those comps, I realize. So how do you think the comps are over the next few quarters? We talked on an absolute dollar basis year-over-year growth? Is the outlook getting a little easier here over the next few quarters or other things we need to take into account there?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think, Jeff, it all comes down to execution. We try not to concentrate on the comps internally. That being said, I mentioned that after the first quarter we felt the second first part of the year, the first 6 months were obviously the tougher months in
componenttext: I think, Jeff, it all comes down to execution. We try not to concentrate on the comps internally. That being said, I mentioned that after the first quarter we felt the second first part of the year, the first 6 months were obviously the tougher months in terms of comparable. But what we are encouraged by is the customer interest in digital impressions and cone beam. The CEREC story is a compelling one because it can tie all of those things together. So our success in the second half of the year will really come down to sales execution and our expectation is we will continue to execute like we did in the last quarter.
