headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen. Thank you for standing by. Welcome to Patterson Companies Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] This conference is being recorded today, Tuesday, November 23, 2010. I would now like to turn the
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen. Thank you for standing by. Welcome to Patterson Companies Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] This conference is being recorded today, Tuesday, November 23, 2010. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to Scott Anderson, President and CEO. Please go ahead.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Alicia. Good morning and thanks for participating in our second quarter earnings conference call. Joining me today is Steve Armstrong, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. At the conclusion of our formal remarks, Steve and
componenttext:
Thank you, Alicia. Good morning and thanks for participating in our second quarter earnings conference call. Joining me today is Steve Armstrong, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. At the conclusion of our formal remarks, Steve and I will be pleased to take your questions.
Since Regulation FD prohibits us from providing investors with any earnings guidance unless we release that information simultaneously, we’ve provided financial guidance for fiscal 2011 in our press release earlier this morning. Our guidance is subject to a number of risks and uncertainties that could cause Patterson’s actual results to vary from our forecast. These risks and uncertainties are discussed in detail in our annual report and on Form 10-K of our SEC filings, and we urge you to review this material.
Turning to our second quarter results. Consolidated sales of $857.4 million were up 5% from $815 million in last year's second quarter. Internal growth generated 1/2 of the sales increase with acquisitions and currency exchange accounting for the balance. Net income of $53.4 million or $0.45 per diluted share rose 8% from $49.3 million or $0.41 per diluted share in the second quarter of fiscal 2010. 
We are encouraged by Patterson's solid second quarter results, which were attained amid the context of a soft economic condition that continued to affect our served markets. 
Sales of Patterson Dental Supply increased 5% to $563.2 million in this year's second quarter. Sales of consumable dental supplies rose 1% from last year's second quarter, reflecting the impact of the economy upon patient demand for dental services. 
We believe the dental market is stabilized, and there could be a modest consumable market growth during the second half of our fiscal year. For the quarter, our Equipment business grew 14% in response to our continuing initiatives aimed at emphasizing the productivity benefits and rapid rates of return of new technology equipment. 
Reflecting the effectiveness of these efforts, sales of CEREC dental restoration system increased nearly 30% in the second quarter. The primary contributor of this growth was more than a 50% increase in new unit sales year-over-year . CEREC sales also benefited from a strong finish to the trade-up program that began earlier this year. For the full year, we continue to believe that CEREC sales should increase by at least 10%, which would represent a very solid performance. 
In addition, sales of Schick digital sensors and our various lines of ConeBeam and panoramic imaging system produced a very strong increase from the year earlier level, another indication of the effectiveness of our sales and marketing efforts. 
Turning now to Patterson Medical. Sales of rehabilitation supply and equipment unit increased 13% to $132.6 million in this year's second quarter, reflecting the positive impact of the June 2010 acquisition of the rehabilitation business of DCC Healthcare. 
Second quarter sales reflect the impact in the U.K. of budgetary constraints being imposed by the British government on its National Health Service. While our security moves in the U.K. are expected to influence domestic sales there, the worldwide business continue to grow nicely. As such, we believe our Rehabilitation business is increasingly well positioned as an ongoing growth driver.
The previously reported acquisition of DCC rehabilitation business is of particular strategic importance to Patterson Medical. In addition to significantly strengthening and expanding Patterson Medical international presence, the acquired businesses bring a stable of trusted and established brand names that encompass an extensive range of products. The integration of the acquired units is proceeding on schedule and expenses related to this activity should continue to gradually moderate over the next few quarters.  As we have stated previously, we are not anticipating a meaningful contribution to our earnings from this acquisition in fiscal 2011. After factoring in the cost of acquisition, immigration and the incremental amortization of intangible assets arising from the valuation process. However, we expect the acquired businesses to be accretive to Patterson's earnings in fiscal 2012. 
Turning to Webster Veterinary. Sales of our veterinary unit increased slightly in this year's second quarter to $161.6 million. We were pleased with Webster's overall performance, although the year-over-year comparability of Webster sales was affected by previously reported changes in the distribution arrangements for certain pharmaceuticals. We estimate that this change over had the effect of reducing Webster second quarter sales growth by approximately 4 to 5 percentage points. Webster will continue to experience the impact of the sales mix on its sales for approximately one more quarter. 
During this quarter, we purchased and retired approximately 1.3 million shares of Patterson stock, which when combined with our quarterly dividends, returned approximately $50 million to shareholders during the period. We will continue to use our remaining repurchase authorization of approximately 4.5 million shares when we believe our cash position and market conditions justify it. 
Regarding our financial outlook contained in this morning's release, we are reiterating our previously issued guidance of $1.89 to $1.99 per diluted share for fiscal 2011. 
As we complete the first half of our year and look ahead to the second half, our fiscal year is unfolding in line with our initial expectations. We believe our dental, veterinary and rehabilitation markets are gradually strengthening. These markets also have attracted long-term fundamentals and our 3 businesses are well positioned to capitalize upon these opportunities. Moreover, we are generating strong operating cash flows, providing us with ample resources for supporting our various growth initiatives. These factors make us optimistic about Patterson's future. 
Thank you. Now Steve Armstrong will review some operational highlights from our second quarter performance. Steve?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Scott. To begin, I just have a couple of additional points on our sales performance for the quarter. On a consolidated basis, currency exchange had a favorable 20 basis point impact on sales growth. Within our Webster Veterinary segment, sales
componenttext:
Thank you, Scott. To begin, I just have a couple of additional points on our sales performance for the quarter. On a consolidated basis, currency exchange had a favorable 20 basis point impact on sales growth. Within our Webster Veterinary segment, sales growth was influenced by 2 negative factors in addition to the shift in mix toward agency sales in the flea and tick and heartworm categories as Scott mentioned. 
First, Webster sales were affected by our decision to exit the Production Animal business as part of Columbus Serem operations prior to its acquisition. This occurred primarily in the third and the fourth quarters of fiscal 2010. And second, as a result of the various pharmaceutical mergers over the past 2 years, certain products previously sold through distribution are now being sold direct by the manufacturer. As we noted during previous conference calls, these factors are expected to generally dissipate in our third fiscal quarter. 
Moving on to our consolidated gross margin. We saw a slight decrease of 10 basis points from the prior year. Two factors contributed to this decrease with the shift in our dental sales mix toward equipment and the impact of being unable to recognize gains from our finance contract sales. I will talk more about this latter item in a couple of minutes. 
The gross margins of the Veterinary and Medical segments both improved for the quarter as product mix and rebates favorably impacted the results of these segments. We improved our operating expense leverage in the quarter by 30 basis points despite absorbing the expenses related to the integration of the acquired DCC rehabilitation asset. 
For the quarter, the Medical segment operating margin was reduced by over 100 basis points by the integration of the DCC asset. But this should begin to improve as we move into the second half of the fiscal year. 
By segment, our first quarter operating margins were 11.3% for Dental, 13.8% for Medical and 5.1% for Veterinary. 
As you may have note in our press release this morning, we became aware late in the quarter that our customer financing agreement whereby we sell the finance contracts to a commercial paper conduit require modification for us to continue to remove the finance contracts from our financial statements when sold. While this was an unpleasant surprise considering the due diligence that we have done to be certain that we comply with the new provisions of the relevant accounting standards, I want to emphasize that it does not change the underlying economics for the customer or Patterson. 
We have nearly completed the technical modifications to our financing agreement, which will bring in into compliance with the provisions of the ASC-860 accounting for the transfer of the financial assets that allow us to remove the contracts from our financial statements as they are sold. We expect to close on the amended agreement in early December. 
In the meantime, the contracts that we sold during this year's first and second quarters, which are the contracts impacted by the new provisions of ASC-860, are shown on our balance sheet as an asset and a liability. The gain connected with these sales has been deferred. 
In our statement of cash flows for the period, the sales of finance contracts has grossed up such as the cash flow from operations is reduced, and the cash flow from financing activities is increased for the cash receipt on the sale of the contract. 
When the amended agreements are closed, our financial statements will reflect the activities of our customer financing activities consistent with our historical presentation. Again, the cash is on the balance sheet and is available for us to use. 
Our balance sheet shows that inventory levels decreased by approximately $30 million during the quarter as planned as we wrap up the CEREC trade-up program and executed on our sales program. The growth in inventory since the beginning of the fiscal year has resulted from the acquisition of the DCC asset during the first quarter. 
Our DSO stands at 44 days in the current period consistent with the prior year, while inventory turns are 7 compared to 7.2 a year ago. The DSO for each period excludes the impact of finance contracts. 
We generated cash flow from operations of approximately $86 million in the second quarter compared to $8 million in the year-earlier period. The cash flow amount that I just provided for the current period adjusts for the impact of the gross up of our financing -- our customer financing operations discussed earlier. 
Our CapEx for the first half of the year includes the completion of the build-out of our new distribution center at South Bend, Indiana and the progress on the new facility for the Patterson Technology Center. It is our expectation that CapEx for the fiscal year should be approximately $35 million. 
With that, I'll turn it back to the conference operator who will poll you for your questions. Alicia?

componenttextpreview: Just a couple of quick questions. One, Steve or Scott, can you give us any indication around the strength in the dental equipment market? Is this sustainable? Is this anything to do with the tax benefits that we're seeing right now?
componenttext: Just a couple of quick questions. One, Steve or Scott, can you give us any indication around the strength in the dental equipment market? Is this sustainable? Is this anything to do with the tax benefits that we're seeing right now?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Lisa, this is Scott. I think the tax benefits we see as a net positive and really a net positive looking out over the next 18 months with the new Section 179 provisions. Our customers now can at least hold improvements into that section, which we think wi
componenttext: Lisa, this is Scott. I think the tax benefits we see as a net positive and really a net positive looking out over the next 18 months with the new Section 179 provisions. Our customers now can at least hold improvements into that section, which we think will help stimulate some renewed interest in office buildups and remodels, things that have been deferred the last 2 years. In terms of strength on the technology side, we do see that as sustainable and really look at this as part of what we've talked about for many years, this transition from film to digital and into new technology products like CEREC. So we do feel that's sustainable, and we appreciate the tax benefits.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: And what do you think the main driver of CEREC is right now? Is it the upgrade cycle that you're currently going through? I know that -- obviously the tax benefits -- you talked a little bit about -- I mean, are there other things that are out there in th
componenttext: And what do you think the main driver of CEREC is right now? Is it the upgrade cycle that you're currently going through? I know that -- obviously the tax benefits -- you talked a little bit about -- I mean, are there other things that are out there in the dental environment that are driving people to a CEREC sale?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well I think you're starting to see the effect of having over 11,000 users in the market and the network of CEREC growing. In terms of promotions, we've always done promotions on CEREC. Another thing that we really benefited from has been the introduction
componenttext: Well I think you're starting to see the effect of having over 11,000 users in the market and the network of CEREC growing. In terms of promotions, we've always done promotions on CEREC. Another thing that we really benefited from has been the introduction of the GALILEOS cone beam machine and its integration with CEREC. And I think the dental community is understanding that the CEREC story is a multifaceted story, not just chair-side restoration story, which is the bulk of the product line, and that digital dentistry is the future. The fact that we still have 6 out of 10 dentists using dental film says that there's a long runway as we move the industry towards a digital platform.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just one question on the consumable side. If I compare you to your next biggest peer, it looks like they trended at about 150 basis points growth in the consumable side, and you came in at about 50 basis points. What are you seeing as far as comp
componenttext: And then just one question on the consumable side. If I compare you to your next biggest peer, it looks like they trended at about 150 basis points growth in the consumable side, and you came in at about 50 basis points. What are you seeing as far as competitive dynamics in the marketplace?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think from all the data points we get from multiple manufacturers, we feel we're growing slightly above market on the consumable side and obviously, dramatically above market on the technology and equipment side. I think that we're encouraged by, as we
componenttext: I think from all the data points we get from multiple manufacturers, we feel we're growing slightly above market on the consumable side and obviously, dramatically above market on the technology and equipment side. I think that we're encouraged by, as we look at the market and our customer base rather than our competitor, is we've seen stabilization. We're starting to see some rolling 12-month averages on some key product categories that we carry starting to strengthen. And as I said in my opening comments, we look for just the gradual strengthening of the consumable market. So I think we're very comfortable with the position we're at and think that there will be better underlying market dynamics in the next 12, 24, 36 months for the dental space.

componenttext: Our basic, our chair unit, cabinetry lines, John, was down just slightly from prior year. As we said, CEREC was up over 30% and our digital platforms obviously were up substantially. So all things being said, I think they executed well across all product lines.

componenttext: Well, I think we're still in an environment where our visibility isn't as clear as what we could have said 3, 4, 5 years ago. componenttext: Well, I think -- and I'll answer this first and let Scott jump in here. I think you're seeing a combination of all of that, John. We're getting some of the Merial business back that we might have had leaked off to competitors when we weren't carrying those lines. There's obviously customer preferences. We want to make sure the customer has choices, and so we have the products available to them. But the dosages are increasing, so we got to be getting something from someone.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from the line of Derek Leckow with Barrington Research.
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Derek Leckow with Barrington Research.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just on the 179 provisions as they relate to lease hold improvements, I'm just curious if you think we're going to see this manifest itself in sort of a higher touch sales activity ahead of ultimately these orders being filled and installed? Is it going t
componenttext: Just on the 179 provisions as they relate to lease hold improvements, I'm just curious if you think we're going to see this manifest itself in sort of a higher touch sales activity ahead of ultimately these orders being filled and installed? Is it going to require a lot more consultative work with your dental customers to get those deals closed?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, Derek, and I would say one of our strengths is we've always had a very high touch consultative relationship with our customers. So we just see the beefing up of the tax benefit as a net positive for the customer to be a part of what we're doing and we
componenttext: No, Derek, and I would say one of our strengths is we've always had a very high touch consultative relationship with our customers. So we just see the beefing up of the tax benefit as a net positive for the customer to be a part of what we're doing and we're very aggressively marketing that is to make sure the customer base in all 3 businesses know about the changes and sit down with their tax advisers, so they're completely informed when they start laying out their decisions. And as we've talked about before, a lot of projects were ready to go and in the fall of 2008, were stopped because of uncertainty. So it's our job to get those projects rolling again.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: And you'd mentioned that your order book was starting to grow last quarter. Just wondered, you also mentioned today that your visibility still isn't where you'd like it to be but is your visibility better than it was, say, 6 to 12 months ago?
componenttext: And you'd mentioned that your order book was starting to grow last quarter. Just wondered, you also mentioned today that your visibility still isn't where you'd like it to be but is your visibility better than it was, say, 6 to 12 months ago?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I would say definitely it's better than it was 6 to 12 months ago and hopefully, it's never again like it was 6 to 12 months ago.
componenttext: Yes. I would say definitely it's better than it was 6 to 12 months ago and hopefully, it's never again like it was 6 to 12 months ago.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. All right. Good. And then just on the veterinary margins. I wonder if are you anticipating a period of time during which the vet margins can improve? And what is it going to take to improve the margins in that business?
componenttext: Okay. All right. Good. And then just on the veterinary margins. I wonder if are you anticipating a period of time during which the vet margins can improve? And what is it going to take to improve the margins in that business?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think what it's going to take to improve the margin is building out the value-added platform in a very similar to what Patterson's philosophy is on taking care of the customers. So there are opportunities outside the pharmaceuticals in terms of so
componenttext: Well, I think what it's going to take to improve the margin is building out the value-added platform in a very similar to what Patterson's philosophy is on taking care of the customers. So there are opportunities outside the pharmaceuticals in terms of software and equipment and service. Those are all areas that overtime we need to execute on to build out a business that has a sustainable, expanding operating margins.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: And where do you feel the operating margins is going?
componenttext: And where do you feel the operating margins is going?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think over the coming years, they can get up into the high-single digits, and then it's just a matter of driving profitable revenue from there. But there's still a lot of work to be done. It's a different marketplace than dental, so it's not going to ha
componenttext: I think over the coming years, they can get up into the high-single digits, and then it's just a matter of driving profitable revenue from there. But there's still a lot of work to be done. It's a different marketplace than dental, so it's not going to happen overnight.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010

componenttext: You are still adding personnel there. Is that something that's going on with new branch offices? Or what's happening with regard to the branch offices?

componenttext: The footprint is fairly well established with Webster particularly after we did the Columbus Serum acquisition that really gave us strength in the Ohio Valley region. But adding sales reps and expanding geography is definitely in the playbook of Webster.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from the line of Robert Jones with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: The next question is from the line of Robert Jones with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I just want to move over to Medical business. On the budgetary constraints being imposed by the U.K. government, can you elaborate a little bit on the nature of these cuts? Is it lower reimbursement on specific therapies? And then I guess just beyond
componenttext: Yes, I just want to move over to Medical business. On the budgetary constraints being imposed by the U.K. government, can you elaborate a little bit on the nature of these cuts? Is it lower reimbursement on specific therapies? And then I guess just beyond the U.K, are you seeing or do you have any expectation that we could see some budgetary constraints in other relevant countries such as France?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we have seen the initial softness driven by the austerity measures. Really the softness in our Medical business came from that. It also came from -- we saw tighter school budgets during the football bidding season that impacted sales at Medco, our s
componenttext: Well, we have seen the initial softness driven by the austerity measures. Really the softness in our Medical business came from that. It also came from -- we saw tighter school budgets during the football bidding season that impacted sales at Medco, our sports medicine business. While the top line was affected, the Medco management team did a great job with product mix to protect the bottom line results. In addition at Medical, we made the strategic decision to exit some businesses out from our Mobilis acquisitions. So I would say we'll react to market conditions. We think going forward, our strength in these markets, the U.K. and France, really gives us an opportunity to gain market share regardless of the market conditions. I would say and Steve mentioned in his comments, our international dealer business was very strong in the quarter. It's growing double digits. So I think it's too early to tell in terms of the crystal ball on the austerity measures.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, it's helpful. And then I guess just given the EPS to date and the maintained guidance, implying a better back half, can you just maybe qualitatively talk a little bit about it? Is this more market driven from where you sit? Or is it related a lot to
componenttext: Okay, it's helpful. And then I guess just given the EPS to date and the maintained guidance, implying a better back half, can you just maybe qualitatively talk a little bit about it? Is this more market driven from where you sit? Or is it related a lot to seasonality? If you could just maybe give us a sense of that. And then as we've moved from last quarter to this quarter, can you give us a sense of the progression you're seeing month-to-month in dental visits?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'll let Steve talk first about the guidance, and then I'll follow up with dental visits.
componenttext: I'll let Steve talk first about the guidance, and then I'll follow up with dental visits.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think going back to the essence of your question, there is some seasonality. The last half of Patterson year is generally a more productive year. We have more capital activity during that cycle. And there seems to be more dentistry performed during
componenttext: Yes, I think going back to the essence of your question, there is some seasonality. The last half of Patterson year is generally a more productive year. We have more capital activity during that cycle. And there seems to be more dentistry performed during the winter months as sort of licensed consistent people or the kids are in school and a lot of vacations, either of staff or of patients. So you do see higher performance in the third and the fourth quarter out of our business. With that said, I would tell you that the third quarter for the vet business happens to be their lowest production quarter as the northern-tier states freeze up. You've got less mosquitoes and obviously, less heart worm, less flea and tick. And then if you get into the fourth quarter, the vet starts back. They [ph] got back up again. So with regard to the guidance, we're obviously continuing to be cautious. It's a soft market out there, as Scott mentioned. And so we have to be cautious. But at the same time, we're optimistic. Our organizations across the board are doing the old man's job to generate revenues when the customers aren't jumping out of the woods to grab the product out of your hand.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: And I will just follow up on visits. We still see the similar trends in terms of -- we look at products tied to hygiene visits, and they still continue to grow at a faster pace than restorative products. So our theory is and we feel confident that the hyg
componenttext: And I will just follow up on visits. We still see the similar trends in terms of -- we look at products tied to hygiene visits, and they still continue to grow at a faster pace than restorative products. So our theory is and we feel confident that the hygiene chairs are still full in the dental offices, and the challenge continues to be moving people over for restorative work and discretionary procedures. So the 2 big things we look at, obviously, and we've talk about this many times, is consumer confidence and unemployment, and we think as those 2 gradually improve, you'll see underlying market firm up even more. That being said, a lot of our customers have been very proactive in how they move people through their offices and scheduled to increase productivity. And I think the reason technology products have resonated so well in this time of flat market growth is the dentist really looking at ways that they can treat their patients more efficiently and also have a much better patient experience in products like digital x-ray and CEREC surely increase the patient experience in a dental office.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from the line of Richard Close with Jefferies.
componenttext: The next question is from the line of Richard Close with Jefferies.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we've never really broken out our International business and our international margins. It's different by unit. I would tell you that the international margins in the Medical business we would expect to improve. Obviously right now, they're being im
componenttext: Well, we've never really broken out our International business and our international margins. It's different by unit. I would tell you that the international margins in the Medical business we would expect to improve. Obviously right now, they're being impacted by the -- to some degree even by the residuals of the Mobilis acquisition that we did a year and a half ago but also by the acquisition of the DCC Healthcare properties that we did earlier this year. And so we're still I think predicting and expecting that the operating margins for the Medical business in total will move up into the mid to high teen as we go forward. They have to continue to make investments in their business. We're going to allow them to do that, which will use up some of that potential margin expansion. But over time, we expect those margins up in the high teens.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, with a great deal of certainty, I will tell you that we would expect that those gains will be reestablished in the third quarter. There's no absolute certainty because we still have to finalize the contract amendment that we're working on. But those
componenttext: Well, with a great deal of certainty, I will tell you that we would expect that those gains will be reestablished in the third quarter. There's no absolute certainty because we still have to finalize the contract amendment that we're working on. But those are nearly done, agreed to in principle and all fashion. They've been through the lawyer abuse and so forth. So I think what you're going to see, Richard, is we'll get those gains back very quickly here in the third quarter as we sign those new agreements.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010

componenttext: I'm sorry, on the other income line?

componenttext: Or the other expense line?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, in the other -- you've got a combination of interest income and interest expense. We wouldn't expect a lot of change in the interest expense that stabilized interest income as we sell off these contracts completely. Now we get them off our balance s
componenttext: Well, in the other -- you've got a combination of interest income and interest expense. We wouldn't expect a lot of change in the interest expense that stabilized interest income as we sell off these contracts completely. Now we get them off our balance sheet. Some of that interest income that we record on those contracts, when we carry them, will be replaced by the gain. And then in the other category, you've got some FX expense in there this year. I think it was actually a gain last year. And then you may recall that we invested in a group called VetSource that is a home-delivery capability and pharmacy management opportunity for the vet office clinic. And we have that on an equity investment. We have about 30% interest in that business. And so we had to pick up their operations under the accounting rules and that other category under equity accounting.

componenttext: I think it's still it's just market conditions. I would say 6 months through the year we feel we're right on plan. We obviously have some momentum in all of our businesses. But we're still competing on a playing field with limited growth across all 3 businesses in terms of market growth. So we're just, I would say we're just being cautious and -- but we're still very optimistic about how we can finish the second half of the year.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: We don't comment obviously, A.J., specifically on acquisitions. But we feel that we are a great strategic acquirer. Most of our acquisitions are relationship based and come around timing of family-owned businesses. We also will pay fair value for business
componenttext: We don't comment obviously, A.J., specifically on acquisitions. But we feel that we are a great strategic acquirer. Most of our acquisitions are relationship based and come around timing of family-owned businesses. We also will pay fair value for businesses even in times like this. So we see our position in terms of capital allocation. That's one of our strategies. If the right businesses come up for acquisition, we definitely will be a player.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010

componenttext: One question on that number, Scott. I guess as I look at the next few quarters, the comps actually get a lot easier than this 45% comp you guys came up against this quarter. But the year-over-year growth numbers aren't always the best way to look at those comps, I realize. So how do you think the comps are over the next few quarters? We talked on an absolute dollar basis for year-over-year growth. Is it -- is the outlook getting a little easier here over the next few quarters or are there things we need to not take into account there?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well I think, Jeff, it all comes down to execution. We try not to concentrate on the comps internally. That being said, I mentioned that after the first quarter that we felt the second first part of the year, the first 6 months were obviously the tougher
componenttext: Well I think, Jeff, it all comes down to execution. We try not to concentrate on the comps internally. That being said, I mentioned that after the first quarter that we felt the second first part of the year, the first 6 months were obviously the tougher months in terms of comparable. But what we are encouraged by is the customer interest in CAD/CAM, the customer interest in digital impressions, in ConeBeam, and then the CEREC story is a compelling one because it can tie all those things together. So our success in the second half of the year will really come down to sales execution, and our expectation is we will continue to execute like we did in the last quarter.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: All right. Great. And then I don't know if you guys saw the New York Times article out today on 3D imaging and then especially with regards to the ConeBeam imaging in dental and the high levels of radiation they're talking about. And that -- it's a pretty
componenttext: All right. Great. And then I don't know if you guys saw the New York Times article out today on 3D imaging and then especially with regards to the ConeBeam imaging in dental and the high levels of radiation they're talking about. And that -- it's a pretty negative article. I guess my question is do you think anything headline risk like that could slow down uptake of demand on the 3D side? How should we think about that specifically?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I haven't seen the article so I won't comment on that specifically. But I think you'll see an evolution in the products in terms of the ability to shoot not only 3D but 2D and have the clinician make the choice in terms of what type of image they're
componenttext: Yes, I haven't seen the article so I won't comment on that specifically. But I think you'll see an evolution in the products in terms of the ability to shoot not only 3D but 2D and have the clinician make the choice in terms of what type of image they're going to -- so I'll just leave it that for now.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010

componenttext: All right. And internally, have you guys heard any discussion from the dentists on competitive advantage for one system over another? Or do you see any risk the whole category with this higher radiation? How do you think about that maybe?

componenttext: No. I don't want to get into the granularity of comparing systems. I think what you have is you have some great manufacturers across the board and market conditions dictate. The firms with the largest R&D budgets will be able to capitalize on any market changes that are driven by those concerns. And we feel we've got some very strong partners in Sirona and Planmeca and others that can react if that's the case.

componenttext: Yes, fair enough. And then, Steve, a couple of questions just on the margin front. Obviously in the past, you guys have guided kind of 40 to 60 basis point operating margin expansion. headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen. Thank you for standing by. Welcome to Patterson Companies Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] This conference is being recorded today, Tuesday, November 23, 2010. I would now like to turn the co
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen. Thank you for standing by. Welcome to Patterson Companies Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] This conference is being recorded today, Tuesday, November 23, 2010. I would now like to turn the conference over to Scott Anderson, President and CEO. Please go ahead.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Alicia. Good morning and thanks for participating in our second quarter earnings conference call. Joining me today is Steve Armstrong, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. At the conclusion of our formal remarks, Steve and
componenttext:
Thank you, Alicia. Good morning and thanks for participating in our second quarter earnings conference call. Joining me today is Steve Armstrong, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. At the conclusion of our formal remarks, Steve and I will be pleased to take your questions.
Since Regulation FD prohibits us from providing investors with any earnings guidance unless we release that information simultaneously, we’ve provided financial guidance for fiscal 2011 in our press release earlier this morning. Our guidance is subject to a number of risks and uncertainties that could cause Patterson’s actual results to vary from our forecast. These risks and uncertainties are discussed in detail in our annual report and on Form 10-K of our SEC filings, and we urge you to review this material.
Turning to our second quarter results. Consolidated sales of $857.4 million were up 5% from $815 million in last year's second quarter. Internal growth generated 1/2 of the sales increase with acquisitions and currency exchange accounting for the balance. Net income of $53.4 million or $0.45 per diluted share rose 8% from $49.3 million or $0.41 per diluted share in the second quarter of fiscal 2010. 
We are encouraged by Patterson's solid second quarter results, which were attained amid the context of a soft economic conditions that continued to affect our served markets. 
Sales of Patterson Dental Supply increased 5% to $563.2 million in this year's second quarter. Sales of consumable dental supplies rose 1% from last year's second quarter, reflecting the impact of the economy upon patient demand for dental services. 
We believe the dental market is stabilized, and there could be a modest consumable market growth during the second half of our fiscal year. For the quarter, our Equipment business grew 14% in response to our continuing initiatives aimed at emphasizing the productivity benefits and rapid rates of return of new technology equipment. 
Reflecting the effectiveness of these efforts, sales of CEREC dental restoration system increased nearly 30% in the second quarter. The primary contributor of this growth was more than a 50% increase in new unit sales year-over-year . CEREC sales also benefited from a strong finish to the trade-up program that began earlier this year. For the full year, we continue to believe that CEREC sales should increase by at least 10%, which would represent a very solid performance. 
In addition, sales of Schick digital sensors and our various lines of ConeBeam and panoramic imaging system produced a very strong increase from the year earlier level, another indication of the effectiveness of our sales and marketing efforts. 
Turning now to Patterson Medical. Sales of rehabilitation supply and equipment unit increased 13% to $132.6 million in this year's second quarter, reflecting the positive impact of the June 2010 acquisition of the rehabilitation business of DCC Healthcare. 
Second quarter sales reflect the impact in the U.K. of budgetary constraints being imposed by the British government on its National Health Service. While our security moves in the U.K. are expected to influence domestic sales there, the worldwide business continued to grow nicely. As such, we believe our Rehabilitation business is increasingly well positioned as an ongoing growth driver.
The previously reported acquisition of DCC rehabilitation business is of particular strategic importance to Patterson Medical. In addition to significantly strengthening and expanding Patterson Medical international presence, the acquired businesses bring a stable of trusted and established brand names that encompass an extensive range of products. The integration of the acquired units is proceeding on schedule and expenses related to this activity should continue to gradually moderate over the next few quarters.  As we have stated previously, we are not anticipating a meaningful contribution to our earnings from this acquisition in fiscal 2011. After factoring in the cost of acquisition, integration and the incremental amortization of intangible assets arising from the valuation process. However, we expect the acquired businesses to be accretive to Patterson's earnings in fiscal 2012. 
Turning to Webster Veterinary. Sales of our veterinary unit increased slightly in this year's second quarter to $161.6 million. We were pleased with Webster's overall performance, although the year-over-year comparability of Webster sales was affected by previously reported changes in the distribution arrangements for certain pharmaceuticals. We estimate that this change over had the effect of reducing Webster second quarter sales growth by approximately 4 to 5 percentage points. Webster will continue to experience the impact of the sales mix on its sales for approximately one more quarter. 
During this quarter, we purchased and retired approximately 1.3 million shares of Patterson stock, which when combined with our quarterly dividend, returned approximately $50 million to shareholders during the period. We will continue to use our remaining repurchase authorization of approximately 4.5 million shares when we believe our cash position and market conditions justify it. 
Regarding our financial outlook contained in this morning's release, we are reiterating our previously issued guidance of $1.89 to $1.99 per diluted share for fiscal 2011. 
As we complete the first half of our year and look ahead to the second half, our fiscal year has unfolded in line with our initial expectations. We believe our dental, veterinary and rehabilitation markets are gradually strengthening. These markets also have attractive long-term fundamentals and our 3 businesses are well positioned to capitalize upon these opportunities. Moreover, we are generating strong operating cash flows, providing us with ample resources for supporting our various growth initiatives. These factors make us optimistic about Patterson's future. 
Thank you. Now Steve Armstrong will review some operational highlights from our second quarter performance. Steve?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Scott. To begin, I just have a couple of additional points on our sales performance for the quarter. On a consolidated basis, currency exchange had a favorable 20 basis point impact on sales growth. Within our Webster Veterinary segment, sales
componenttext:
Thank you, Scott. To begin, I just have a couple of additional points on our sales performance for the quarter. On a consolidated basis, currency exchange had a favorable 20 basis point impact on sales growth. Within our Webster Veterinary segment, sales growth was influenced by 2 negative factors in addition to the shift in mix toward agency sales in the flea and tick and heartworm categories that Scott mentioned. 
First, Webster sales were affected by our decision to exit the Production Animal business as part of Columbus Serem operations prior to its acquisition. This occurred primarily in the third and the fourth quarters of fiscal 2010. And second, as a result of the various pharmaceutical mergers over the past 2 years, certain products previously sold through distribution are now being sold direct by the manufacturer. As we noted during previous conference calls, these factors are expected to generally dissipate in our third fiscal quarter. 
Moving on to our consolidated gross margin. We saw a slight decrease of 10 basis points from the prior year. Two factors contributed to this decrease with the shift in our dental sales mix toward equipment and the impact of being unable to recognize gains from our finance contract sales. I will talk more about this latter item in a couple of minutes. 
The gross margins of the Veterinary and Medical segments both improved for the quarter as product mix and rebates favorably impacted the results of these segments. We improved our operating expense leverage in the quarter by 30 basis points despite absorbing the expenses related to the integration of the acquired DCC rehabilitation asset. 
For the quarter, the Medical segment operating margin was reduced by over 100 basis points by the integration of the DCC asset. But this should begin to improve as we move into the second half of the fiscal year. 
By segment, our first quarter operating margins were 11.3% for Dental, 13.8% for Medical and 5.1% for Veterinary. 
As you may have note in our press release this morning, we became aware late in the quarter that our customer financing agreement whereby we sell the finance contracts to a commercial paper conduit require modification for us to continue to remove the finance contracts from our financial statements when sold. While this was an unpleasant surprise considering the due diligence that we have done to be certain that we comply with the new provisions of the relevant accounting standards, I want to emphasize that it does not change the underlying economics for the customer or Patterson. 
We have nearly completed the technical modifications to our financing agreement, which will bring it into compliance with the provisions of the ASC-860 accounting for the transfer of the financial assets that allow us to remove the contracts from our financial statements as they are sold. We expect to close on the amended agreement in early December. In the meantime, the contracts that we sold during this year's first and second quarters, which are the contracts impacted by the new provisions of ASC-860, are shown on our balance sheet as an asset and a liability. The gain connected with these sales has been deferred. 
In our statement of cash flows for the period, the sales of finance contracts has grossed up such as the cash flow from operations is reduced, and the cash flow from financing activities is increased for the cash received on a sale of the contract. 
When the amended agreements are closed, our financial statements will reflect the activities of our customer financing activities consistent with our historical presentation. Again, the cash is on the balance sheet and is available for us to use. 
Our balance sheet shows that inventory levels decreased by approximately $30 million during the quarter as planned as we wrap up the CEREC trade-up program and executed on our sales program. The growth in inventory since the beginning of the fiscal year has resulted from the acquisition of the DCC asset during the first quarter. 
Our DSO stands at 44 days in the current period consistent with the prior year, while inventory turns are at 7 compared to 7.2 a year ago. The DSO for each period excludes the impact of finance contracts. 
We generated cash flow from operations of approximately $86 million in the second quarter compared to $8 million in the year-earlier period. The cash flow amount that I just provided for the current period adjusts for the impact of the gross up of our financing -- our customer financing operations discussed earlier. 
Our CapEx for the first half of the year includes the completion of the build-out of our new distribution center at South Bend, Indiana and the progress on the new facility for the Patterson Technology Center. It is our expectation that CapEx for the fiscal year should be approximately $35 million. 
With that, I'll turn it back to the conference operator who will poll you for your questions. Alicia?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The first question is from the line of Lisa Gill with JPMorgan.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of quick questions. One, Steve or Scott, can you give us any indication around the strength in the dental equipment market? Is this sustainable? Is this anything to do with the tax benefits that we're seeing right now?
componenttext: Just a couple of quick questions. One, Steve or Scott, can you give us any indication around the strength in the dental equipment market? Is this sustainable? Is this anything to do with the tax benefits that we're seeing right now?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Lisa, this is Scott. I think the tax benefits we see as a net positive and really a net positive looking out over the next 18 months with the new Section 179 provisions. Our customers now can add lease hold improvements into that section, which we think w
componenttext: Lisa, this is Scott. I think the tax benefits we see as a net positive and really a net positive looking out over the next 18 months with the new Section 179 provisions. Our customers now can add lease hold improvements into that section, which we think will help stimulate some renewed interest in office buildups and remodels, things that have been deferred the last 2 years. In terms of strength on the technology side, we do see that as sustainable and really look at this as part of what we've talked about for many years, this transition from film to digital and into new technology products like CEREC. So we do feel that's sustainable, and we appreciate the tax benefits.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: And what do you think the main driver of CEREC is right now? Is it the upgrade cycle that you're currently going through? I know that -- obviously the tax benefits -- you talked a little bit about -- I mean, are there other things that are out there in th
componenttext: And what do you think the main driver of CEREC is right now? Is it the upgrade cycle that you're currently going through? I know that -- obviously the tax benefits -- you talked a little bit about -- I mean, are there other things that are out there in the dental environment that are driving people to a CEREC sale?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well I think you're starting to see the effect of having over 11,000 users in the market and the network of CEREC growing. In terms of promotions, we've always done promotions on CEREC. Another thing that we really benefited from has been the introduction
componenttext: Well I think you're starting to see the effect of having over 11,000 users in the market and the network of CEREC growing. In terms of promotions, we've always done promotions on CEREC. Another thing that we really benefited from has been the introduction of the GALILEOS cone beam machine and its integration with CEREC. And I think the dental community is understanding that the CEREC story is a multifaceted story, not just a chair-side restoration story, which is the bulk of the product line, and that digital dentistry is the future. The fact that we still have 6 out of 10 dentists using dental film says that there's a long runway as we move the industry towards a digital platform.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just one question on the consumable side. If I compare you to your next biggest peer, it looks like they trended at about 150 basis points growth in the consumable side, and you came in at about 50 basis points. What are you seeing as far as comp
componenttext: And then just one question on the consumable side. If I compare you to your next biggest peer, it looks like they trended at about 150 basis points growth in the consumable side, and you came in at about 50 basis points. What are you seeing as far as competitive dynamics in the marketplace?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think from all the data points we get from multiple manufacturers, we feel we're growing slightly above market on the consumable side and obviously, dramatically above market on the technology and equipment side. I think what we're encouraged by, as we
componenttext: I think from all the data points we get from multiple manufacturers, we feel we're growing slightly above market on the consumable side and obviously, dramatically above market on the technology and equipment side. I think what we're encouraged by, as we look at the market and our customer base rather than our competitor, is we've seen stabilization. We're starting to see some rolling 12-month averages on some key product categories that we carry starting to strengthen. And as I said in my opening comments, we look for just the gradual strengthening of the consumable market. So I think we're very comfortable with the position we're at and think that there will be better underlying market dynamics in the next 12, 24, 36 months for the dental space.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from the line of John Kreger with William Blair.
componenttext: The next question is from the line of John Kreger with William Blair.

componenttext: Just a followup to Lisa's question about dental growth. The 14% you saw in equipment, how does that breakdown between the higher tech categories and basic?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our basic, our chair unit, cabinetry lines, John, was down just slightly from prior year. As we said, CEREC was up over 30% and our digital platforms obviously were up substantially. And I would just note that this was not an easy comp for our dental grou
componenttext: Our basic, our chair unit, cabinetry lines, John, was down just slightly from prior year. As we said, CEREC was up over 30% and our digital platforms obviously were up substantially. And I would just note that this was not an easy comp for our dental group either. We were up roughly 3% a year ago when most of the market was down double digits. So all things being said, I think they executed well across all product lines.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Great. And as you look at your pipeline, as we head into calendar year end, how do you feel? And how does that compare to prior years?
componenttext: Great. And as you look at your pipeline, as we head into calendar year end, how do you feel? And how does that compare to prior years?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we're still in an environment where our visibility isn't as clear as what we could have said 3, 4, 5 years ago. But we're encouraged by the tax changes in Section 179 and 168. We know that a lot of projects have been deferred, and as dentist
componenttext: Well, I think we're still in an environment where our visibility isn't as clear as what we could have said 3, 4, 5 years ago. But we're encouraged by the tax changes in Section 179 and 168. We know that a lot of projects have been deferred, and as dentists gain confidence there's definitely great incentives in front of them and access to capital to renew those projects, and our sales team is out there making sure that we get our lion's share of those projects.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010

componenttext: Great. And then just one other question, this one about the vet business. The 4% to 5% hit you mentioned by the shift to agency and the flea and tick category, what sort of an impact did that have on the operating income line, if any?

componenttext: John, this is Steve. Generally, that causes, in a ratio perspective, it actually causes it to improve. Dollars and cents it has very little impact.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's pretty new to work. We actually went back and again this quarter like we did last quarter. We look at not only the revenue mix, we also looked at what's happening to doses. And we know doses is going out the door. It's continuing to grow. So we're pu
componenttext: It's pretty new to work. We actually went back and again this quarter like we did last quarter. We look at not only the revenue mix, we also looked at what's happening to doses. And we know doses is going out the door. It's continuing to grow. So we're putting more dollars on the operating line and it does as well when you have that agency increase in your revenue line. You do get some better metrics but it's mostly what we're paying attention it goes out the door.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: So what do you think is really happening here? Are you adding new customers, tapping into the Merial lines that you didn't have before? Are you seeing convergence of customers that were previously buying other brands that are switching?
componenttext: So what do you think is really happening here? Are you adding new customers, tapping into the Merial lines that you didn't have before? Are you seeing convergence of customers that were previously buying other brands that are switching?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think -- and I'll answer this first and let Scott jump in here. I think you've seeing a combination of all of that, John. We're getting some of the Merial business back that we might have had leaked off to competitors when we weren't carrying thos
componenttext: Well, I think -- and I'll answer this first and let Scott jump in here. I think you've seeing a combination of all of that, John. We're getting some of the Merial business back that we might have had leaked off to competitors when we weren't carrying those lines. There's obviously customer preferences. We want to make sure the customer has choices, and so we have the products available to them. But the dosages are increasing, so we got to be getting something from someone.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from the line of Derek Leckow with Barrington Research.
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Derek Leckow with Barrington Research.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just on the 179 provisions as they relate to lease hold improvements, I'm just curious if you think we're going to see this manifest itself in sort of a higher touch sales activity ahead of ultimately these orders being filled and installed? Is it going t
componenttext: Just on the 179 provisions as they relate to lease hold improvements, I'm just curious if you think we're going to see this manifest itself in sort of a higher touch sales activity ahead of ultimately these orders being filled and installed? Is it going to require a lot more consultative work with your dental customers to get those deals closed?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, Derek, and I would say one of our strengths is we've always had a very high touch consultative relationship with our customers. So we just see the beefing up of the tax benefit as a net positive for the customer. Part of what we're doing and we're ver
componenttext: No, Derek, and I would say one of our strengths is we've always had a very high touch consultative relationship with our customers. So we just see the beefing up of the tax benefit as a net positive for the customer. Part of what we're doing and we're very aggressively marketing that is to make sure the customer base in all 3 businesses know about the changes and sit down with their tax advisers, so they're completely informed when they start laying out their decisions. And as we've talked about before, a lot of projects were ready to go and in the fall of 2008, were stopped because of uncertainty. So it's our job to get those projects rolling again.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: And you'd mentioned that your order book was starting to grow last quarter. Just wondered, you also mentioned today that your visibility still isn't where you'd like it to be but is your visibility better than it was, say, 6 to 12 months ago?
componenttext: And you'd mentioned that your order book was starting to grow last quarter. Just wondered, you also mentioned today that your visibility still isn't where you'd like it to be but is your visibility better than it was, say, 6 to 12 months ago?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I would say definitely it's better than it was 6 to 12 months ago and hopefully, it's never again like it was 6 to 12 months ago.
componenttext: Yes. I would say definitely it's better than it was 6 to 12 months ago and hopefully, it's never again like it was 6 to 12 months ago.

componenttext: Okay. All right. Good. And then just on the veterinary margins. I wonder if -- are you anticipating a period of time during which the vet margins can improve? And what is it going to take to improve the margins in that business?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think what it's going to take to improve the margin is building out the value-added platform in a very similar to what Patterson's philosophy is on taking care of the customers. So there are opportunities outside of pharmaceuticals in terms of sof
componenttext: Well, I think what it's going to take to improve the margin is building out the value-added platform in a very similar to what Patterson's philosophy is on taking care of the customers. So there are opportunities outside of pharmaceuticals in terms of software and equipment and service. Those are all areas that overtime we need to execute on to build out a business that has a sustainable, expanding operating margins.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: And where do you see those operating margins going?
componenttext: And where do you see those operating margins going?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think over the coming years, they can get up into the high-single digits, and then it's just a matter of driving profitable revenue from there. But there's still a lot of work to be done. It's a different marketplace than dental, so it's not going to ha
componenttext: I think over the coming years, they can get up into the high-single digits, and then it's just a matter of driving profitable revenue from there. But there's still a lot of work to be done. It's a different marketplace than dental, so it's not going to happen overnight.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010

componenttext: And are you still adding personnel there. Is that something that's going on with new branch offices? Or what's happening with regard to the branch offices?

componenttext: The footprint is fairly well established with Webster particularly after we did the Columbus Serum acquisition that really gave us strength in the Ohio Valley region. But adding sales reps and expanding geography is definitely in the playbook of Webster.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010

componenttext: The next question is from the line of Robert Jones with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I just want to move over to Medical business. On the budgetary constraints being imposed by the U.K. government, can you elaborate a little bit on the nature of these cuts? Is it lower reimbursement on specific therapies? And then I guess just beyond
componenttext: Yes, I just want to move over to Medical business. On the budgetary constraints being imposed by the U.K. government, can you elaborate a little bit on the nature of these cuts? Is it lower reimbursement on specific therapies? And then I guess just beyond the U.K, are you seeing or do you have any expectation that we could see some budgetary constraints in other relevant countries such as France?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we have seen the initial softness driven by the austerity measures. Really the softness in our Medical business came from that. It also came from -- we saw tighter school budgets during the football bidding season that impacted sales at Medco, our s
componenttext: Well, we have seen the initial softness driven by the austerity measures. Really the softness in our Medical business came from that. It also came from -- we saw tighter school budgets during the football bidding season that impacted sales at Medco, our sports medicine business. While the top line was affected, the Medco management team did a great job with product mix to protect the bottom line results. In addition at Medical, we made the strategic decision to exit some businesses out from our Mobilis acquisitions. So I would say we'll react to market conditions. We think going forward, our strength in these markets, the U.K. and France, really gives us an opportunity to gain market share regardless of the market conditions. I would say and Steve mentioned it in his comments, our international dealer business was very strong in the quarter. It's growing double digits. So I think it's too early to tell in terms of the crystal ball on the austerity measures.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then I guess just given the EPS to date and the maintained guidance, implying a better back half, can you just maybe qualitatively talk a little bit about it? Is this more market driven from where you sit? Or is it related a lot
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then I guess just given the EPS to date and the maintained guidance, implying a better back half, can you just maybe qualitatively talk a little bit about it? Is this more market driven from where you sit? Or is it related a lot to seasonality? If you could just maybe give us a sense of that? And then as we've moved from last quarter to this quarter, can you give us a sense of the progression you're seeing month-to-month in dental visits?

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'll let Steve talk first about the guidance, and then I'll follow up with dental visits.
componenttext: I'll let Steve talk first about the guidance, and then I'll follow up with dental visits.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think going back to the essence of your question, there is some seasonality. The last half of Patterson’s year is generally a more productive year. We have more capital activity during that cycle. And there seems to be more dentistry performed du
componenttext: Yes, I think going back to the essence of your question, there is some seasonality. The last half of Patterson’s year is generally a more productive year. We have more capital activity during that cycle. And there seems to be more dentistry performed during the winter months as sort of licensed consistent people or the kids are in school and a lot of vacations, either of staff or of patients. So you do see higher performance in the third and the fourth quarter out of our business. With that said, I would tell you that the third quarter for the vet business happens to be their lowest production quarter as the northern-tier states freeze up. You've got less mosquitoes, obviously, less heart worm, less flea and tick. And then as you get into the fourth quarter, the vet starts stocking back up again. So with regard to the guidance, we're obviously continuing to be cautious. It's a soft market out there, as Scott mentioned. And so we have to be cautious. But at the same time, we're optimistic. Our organizations across the board are doing the old man's job to generate revenues when the customers aren't jumping out of the woods to grab the product out of your hand.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: And I will just follow up on visits. We still see the similar trends in terms of -- we look at products tied to hygiene visits, and they still continue to grow at a faster pace than restorative products. So our theory is and we feel confident in this, tha
componenttext: And I will just follow up on visits. We still see the similar trends in terms of -- we look at products tied to hygiene visits, and they still continue to grow at a faster pace than restorative products. So our theory is and we feel confident in this, that the hygiene chairs are still full in the dental offices, and the challenge continues to be moving people over for restorative work and discretionary procedures. So the 2 big things we look at, obviously, and we've talk about this many times, is consumer confidence and unemployment, and we think as those 2 gradually improve, you'll see underlying market firm up even more. That being said, a lot of our customers have been very proactive in how they move people through their offices and scheduled to increase productivity. And I think the reason technology products have resonated so well in this time of flat market growth is the dentist really are looking at ways that they can treat their patients more efficiently and also have a much better patient experience in products like digital x-ray and CEREC surely increase the patient experience in a dental office.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from the line of Richard Close with Jefferies.
componenttext: The next question is from the line of Richard Close with Jefferies.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we've never really broken out our International business and our international margins. It's different by unit. I would tell you that the international margins in the Medical business we would expect to improve. Obviously right now, they're being im
componenttext: Well, we've never really broken out our International business and our international margins. It's different by unit. I would tell you that the international margins in the Medical business we would expect to improve. Obviously right now, they're being impacted by the -- to some degree even by the residuals of the Mobilis acquisition that we did a year and a half ago but also by the acquisition of the DCC Healthcare properties that we did earlier this year. And so we're still I think predicting and expecting that the operating margins for the Medical business in total will move up into the mid to high teen as we go forward. They have to continue to make investments in their business. We're going to allow them to do that, which will use up some of that potential margin expansion going forward. But over time, we expect those margins up in the high teens.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, with a great deal of certainty, I will tell you that we would expect that those gains will be reestablished in the third quarter. There's no absolute certainty because we still have to finalize the contract amendment that we're working on. But those
componenttext: Well, with a great deal of certainty, I will tell you that we would expect that those gains will be reestablished in the third quarter. There's no absolute certainty because we still have to finalize the contract amendment that we're working on. But those are nearly done, agreed to in principle and all fashion. They've been through the lawyer fees and so forth. So I think what you're going to see, Richard, is we'll get those gains back very quickly here in the third quarter as we sign those new agreements.

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010

headline: Patterson Companies Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, in the other -- you've got a combination of interest income and interest expense. We wouldn't expect a lot of change in the interest expense that has stabilized. Interest income, as we sell off these contracts completely, now we get them off our bal
componenttext: Well, in the other -- you've got a combination of interest income and interest expense. We wouldn't expect a lot of change in the interest expense that has stabilized. Interest income, as we sell off these contracts completely, now we get them off our balance sheet, some of that interest income that we record on those contracts when we carry them will be replaced by the gain. And then in the other category, you've got some FX expense in there this year. I think it was actually a gain last year. And then you may recall that we invested in a group called VetSource that is a home-delivery capability and pharmacy management opportunity for the vet office clinic. And we have that on an equity investment. We have about 30% interest in that business. And so we had to pick up their operations under the accounting rules and that other category, under equity accounting.

componenttext: I think it's still it's just market conditions. I would say 6 months through the year we feel we're right on plan. We obviously have some momentum in all of our businesses. But we're still competing on a playing field with limited growth across all 3 businesses in terms of market growth. So we're just, I would say we're just being cautious and -- but we're still very optimistic about how we can finish the second half of the year.

componenttext: We don't comment obviously, A.J., specifically on acquisitions. But we feel that we are a great strategic acquirer. Most of our acquisitions are relationship based and come around timing of family-owned businesses. We also will pay fair value for businesses even in times like this. So we see our position in terms of capital allocation. That's one of our strategies. If the right businesses come up for acquisition, we definitely will be a player.
